to enforce basic safeguards for railways.\n\nA witness said the trains rose into the air \"forming a pyramid\" as they slammed into each other just outside a suburban station in the Mediterranean port city.\n\nThe prosecutor ordered two train drivers and two assistants be held for 15 days and released several other railway employees, MENA said. city.\n\nThe prosecutor ordered two train drivers and two assistants be held for 15 days and released several other railway employees, MENA said. today after two trains collided near Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria.\n\nAt least 41 people were killed and nearly 180 others injured today after two trains collided near Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria, officials said. The collision occurred when a train from the Egyptian capital Cairo collided with another train coming from Port Said in Khorshid area, Health ministry officials said.\n\nThe transport ministry said that the train coming from Cairo to Alexandria crashed into the back of the train coming from Port Said to Alexandria, which was stationary at Khorsid station when the collision occurred which left at least 41 dead and 179 injured, ahramonline reported quoting a Health ministry statement.\n\nThe driver of the Cairo-Alexandria train has surrendered himself to police and has been transferred to El-Raml police station in Alexandria for investigation, it said.\n\nEgypt's prosecutor-general Nabil Sadiq has ordered an urgent investigation into the collision to find out the reason behind the crash.\n\nPresident El-Sisi has expressed his condolences to the victims and ordered government bodies to follow up on developments from the deadly collision and identify the cause of the accident.\n\n\"The rescue team is currently searching for survivals while ambulances are transferring the injured to nearby hospitals,\" said Magdy Hegazi, undersecretary at the Health ministry.\n\nEarlier, Health Minister advisor Sherif Wadie said that the number of casualties could increase.\n\nThe ministry said 75 ambulances had been deployed at the crash scene to treat casualties and that all the hospitals in Alexandria had been placed on high alert. The cause of the crash is not yet known. The Health ministry is yet to announce the final toll.\n\nTrain accidents are common in Egypt. In 2016, a train derailed in south of Cairo, killing five people, and injuring 27 people in the al-Ayat area.\n\nAnother train derailment in Badr Rashin in Giza killed at least 19 people in 2013.\n\nIn 2012, a collision between a train and school bus on a rail crossing in the town of Manaflut in Upper Egypt killed 51 people, mostly children.\n\nAt least 360 people were killed in 2002 in Egypt's worst train disaster when a major fire engulfed seven carriages of an overcrowded passenger train.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T23:19:00Z", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "source": {"uri": "financialexpress.com", "title": "The Financial Express", "id": "4684"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:19:00", "url": "http://www.financialexpress.com/world-news/egypt-train-collision-kills-41-nearly-180-injured/804948/", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8717555", "image": "http://images.financialexpress.com/2017/08/egyptians-coastal-khorshid-survivors-station-alexandria-collided_661d4390-7eaf-11e7-ba32-a280bea68af6.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "23:19:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

after two trains collided near Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria, officials said.\n\nThe Egyptian cabinet said in a statement that the number of deaths may increase and the final toll will be AP\n\nThe deadly collision took place on Friday after a train travelling to Alexandria from Cairo, crashed into the back of another train coming from the Canal city of Port Said, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, east of Alexandria, the Egyptian Railways Authority said in a statement.\n\nThe area of the collision has been cordoned off by security forces as a rescue team is currently searching for survivors over the night and removing the wreckage off the tracks, it said.\n\nIman Hamdy, 26, a survivor of the accident, said that she was travelling in the train going to Alexandria and noticed that it was already in a bad condition.\n\nThe Al-Masri el-Youm Arabic newspaper quoted her saying that the train abruptly stopped for 15 minutes in Ebies area near Khorshid station when she felt its collision with the another train.\n\nHamdy, who succeeded in escaping from the train through one of the windows, said that she will never forget the large number of injured, mostly women and children, she saw at the accident site.\n\nAnother survivor, 10 year-old Karim Abdel Wahab, said that he couldn't find his mother and brother who were travelling with him in the train.\n\nThe driver of the Cairo-Alexandria train has surrendered himself to police and has been transferred to El-Raml police station in Alexandria for investigation, local media said quoting a health ministry official.\n\nEgypt's prosecutor-general Nabil Sadiq has ordered an urgent investigation into the collision to find out the reason behind the crash.\n\nPresident El-Sisi has expressed "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sleeping_while_on_duty", "score": 2, "id": "565131", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "People gather at the site of a train collision near Egypt's Mediterranean city of Alexandria, on August 11, 2017. At least 36 people were killed when two trains collided\n\nAt least 36 people were killed as two trains collided Friday outside the Mediterranean city of Alexandria, in one of the deadliest in a string of such accidents in Egypt, the health ministry said.\n\nThe crash also injured 123 people, the ministry said in a statement.\n\nFootage on the state broadcaster showed one train had partly keeled over in the crash, and medics were seen moving the dead and injured to ambulances.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, said the crash was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt on the rails. The other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne of them had been heading from Cairo to the northern city of Alexandria and the other from the canal city of Port Said, east of the capital, to Alexandria.\n\nThe dead and injured were initially placed on blankets by the sides of the tracks amid farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria.\n\nAssistant health minister Sharif Wadi told state television that most of the injured had been taken to hospital.\n\nEgypt's transport minister has ordered an investigation into the crash, pledging to \"hold accountable\" whoever was responsible, state television reported.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident had jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nEgyptian security forces stand guard at the site of a deadly train collision near Egypt's Mediterranean city of Alexandria, on August 11, 2017, the latest in a string of such accidents in Egypt\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Months later a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAlmost a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of Cairo.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the busy rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwest Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into bus, truck and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nIn August 2006, at least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 wounded in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, an Egyptian court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died as a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 112, "textStart": 97, "freq": 2}, {"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 1491, "textStart": 1478}, {"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 2509, "textStart": 2500}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 2726, "textStart": 2715}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T16:40:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "title": "Mail Online", "id": "214"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "16:40:00", "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4782684/index.html", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8662368", "image": "http://i.dailymail.co.uk/1/2017/08/11/17/wire-1117421-1502469295-790_636x382.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "16:40:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"1044431", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "At least 44 people were killed and nearly 180 others injured when two trains collided near Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria, officials said.\n\nThe Egyptian cabinet said in a statement that the number of deaths may increase and a final toll will be announced after clearing the debris from the accident site later.\n\nThe deadly collision took place yesterday after a train travelling to Alexandria from Cairo, crashed into the back of another train coming from the Canal city of Port Said, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, east of Alexandria, the Egyptian Railways Authority said in a statement.\n\nThe area of the collision has been cordoned off by security forces as a rescue team is currently searching for survivors over the night and removing the wreckage off the tracks, it said.\n\nTrain movement from Cairo to Alexandria resumed today after the tracks were cleared following the accident, the spokesman for the Ministry of Transportation was quoted as saying by state news agency MENA.\n\nTransportation ministry spokesman Mohammed Ezz said that Cairo-Alexandria train traffic would operate on a single line in both directions until a second track that was damaged in the accident is repaired.\n\nIman Hamdy, 26, a survivor of the accident, said that she was travelling in the train going to Alexandria and noticed that it was already in a bad condition.\n\nThe Al-Masri el-Youm Arabic newspaper quoted her as saying that the train abruptly stopped for 15 minutes in Ebies area near Khorshid station when she felt its collision with the another train.\n\nHamdy, who succeeded in escaping from the train through one of the windows, said that she will never forget the large number of injured, mostly women and children, she saw at the accident site.\n\nAnother survivor, 10 year-old Karim Abdel Wahab, said that he couldn't find his mother and brother who were travelling with him in the train.\n\nThe driver of the Cairo-Alexandria train has surrendered himself to police and has been transferred to El-Raml police station in Alexandria for investigation, local media reported, citing a health ministry official.\n\nEgypt's prosecutor-general Nabil Sadiq has ordered an urgent investigation into the collision to find out the reason behind the crash.\n\nPresident El-Sisi has expressed his condolences to the victims and ordered government bodies to follow up on developments from the deadly collision and identify the cause of the accident.\n\n\"The rescue team is currently searching for survivals while ambulances are transferring the injured to nearby hospitals,\" said Magdy Hegazi, undersecretary at the Health ministry.\n\nThe ministry said 75 ambulances had been deployed at the crash scene to treat casualties and that all the hospitals in Alexandria had been placed on high alert.\n\nTrain accidents are common in Egypt. In 2016, a train derailed in south of Cairo, killing five people, and injuring 27 people in the al-Ayat area.\n\nAnother train derailment in Badr Rashin in Giza killed at least 19 people in 2013.\n\nIn 2012, a collision between a train and school bus on a rail crossing in the town of Manaflut in Upper Egypt killed 51 people, mostly children.\n\nAt least 360 people were killed in 2002 in Egypt's worst train disaster when a major fire engulfed seven carriages of an overcrowded passenger train.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T15:54:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"uri": "business-standard.com", "title": "Business Standard", "id": "405"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "15:54:00", "url": "http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/44-killed-in-egypt-train-collision-179-injured-117081200759_1.html", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8812852", "image": "http://bsmedia.business-standard.com/_media/bs/img/common/no_preview.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "15:54:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Glendale_train_crash", "score": 2, "id": "1169734", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "CAIRO: Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing at least 36 people and injuring about 123, according to the Health Ministry, in the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Railways Authority said a train traveling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nFootage on the state broadcaster showed one train had partly keeled over in the crash, and medics were seen moving the dead and injured to ambulances.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, said the crash was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt on the rails. The other train then crashed into it.\n\nAssociated Press video footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nThe dead and injured were initially placed on blankets by the sides of the tracks running through farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster.\n\nAssistant health minister Sharif Wadi told state television that most of the injured had been taken to hospital.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah El-Sisi sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster, his office said.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's collision was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nThat accident had jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Months later a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAlmost a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of Cairo.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train plowed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the busy rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwest Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into bus, truck and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nIn August 2006, at least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in a collision between two trains traveling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, an Egyptian court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died as a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 3107, "textStart": 3098}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 3324, "textStart": 3313}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T13:41:00Z", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "source": {"uri": "arabnews.com", "title": "Arab News", "id": "4355"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:10:00", "url": "http://www.arabnews.com/node/1143111/middle-east", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8676710", "image": "http://www.arabnews.com/sites/default/files/2017/08/11/968631-466475016.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "13:41:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

cabinet said in a statement that the number of deaths may increase and a final toll will be announced after clearing the debris from the accident site later.\n\nThe deadly collision took place yesterday after a train travelling to Alexandria from Cairo, crashed into the back of another train coming from the Canal city of Port Said, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, east of Alexandria, the Egyptian Railways Authority said in a statement.\n\nThe area of the collision has been cordoned off by security forces as a rescue team is currently searching for survivors over the night and removing the wreckage off the tracks, it said.\n\nTrain movement from Cairo to Alexandria resumed today after the tracks were cleared following the accident, the spokesman for the Ministry of Transportation was quoted as saying by state news agency MENA.\n\nTransportation ministry spokesman Mohammed Ezz said that Cairo-Alexandria train traffic would operate on a single line in both directions until a second track that was damaged in the accident is repaired.\n\nIman Hamdy, 26, a survivor of the accident, said that she was travelling in the train going to Alexandria and noticed that it was already in a bad condition.\n\nThe Al-Masri el-Youm Arabic newspaper quoted her as saying that the train abruptly stopped for 15 minutes in Ebies area near Khorshid station when she felt its collision with the another train.\n\nHamdy, who succeeded in escaping from the train through one of the windows, said that she will never forget the large number of injured, mostly women and children, she saw at the accident site.\n\nAnother survivor, 10 year-old Karim Abdel Wahab, said that he couldn't find his mother and brother who were travelling with him in the It was the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nThe Egyptian Railways Authority said earlier that one of the trains, traveling from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nAfter nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's Health Ministry has further raised the death toll from a train collision just east of the coastal city of Alexandria, saying that 40 people were killed.\n\nThe ministry also says more than 100 people were injured in the collision on Friday. It was the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nThe Egyptian Railways Authority earlier said one of the trains, traveling from the capital of Cairo, crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit. The statement did not say what caused the accident, saying only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nEgypt's Health Ministry has raised to 36 the death toll from a train collision just east of the coastal city of Alexandria.\n\nMinistry spokesman Khaled Megahed told state television that more than a 100 people were also injured in the collision.\n\nThe Egyptian Railways Authority said a train traveling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, hit the back end of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would be investigating.\n\nTwo passenger trains have collided just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing at least 31 people and injuring 109.\n\nTwo senior medical officials in Alexandria, Mohammed Abu Homs and Magdy Hegazy, gave the casualty tolls for the tragedy on Friday, cautioning that the death toll was likely to rise further.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Railways Authority said a train traveling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, hit the back end of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, saying only that the authority's "1044431", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Highlights1The driver of the Cairo-Alexandria train has surrendered himself to police.2He has been transferred to El-Raml police station in Alexandria for investigation3All the hospitals in Alexandria had been placed on high alert.\n\nAt least 44 people were killed and nearly 180 others injured when two trains collided near Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria, officials said.\n\nThe Egyptian cabinet said in a statement that the number of deaths may increase and a final toll will be announced after clearing the debris from the accident site later.\n\nThe deadly collision took place yesterday after a train traveling to Alexandria from Cairo, crashed into the back of another train coming from the Canal city of Port Said, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, east of Alexandria, the Egyptian Railways Authority said in a statement.\n\nThe area of the collision has been cordoned off by security forces as a rescue team is currently searching for survivors over the night and removing the wreckage off the tracks, it said.\n\nTrain movement from Cairo to Alexandria resumed today after the tracks were cleared following the accident, the spokesman for the Ministry of Transportation was quoted as saying by state news agency MENA.\n\nTransportation ministry spokesman Mohammed Ezz said that Cairo-Alexandria train traffic would operate on a single line in both directions until a second track that was damaged in the accident is repaired.\n\nIman Hamdy, 26, a survivor of the accident, said that she was traveling in the train going to Alexandria and noticed that it was already in a bad condition.\n\nThe Al-Masri el-Youm Arabic newspaper quoted her as saying that the train abruptly stopped for 15 minutes in Ebies area near Khorshid station when she felt its collision with the another train.\n\nHamdy, who succeeded in escaping from the train through one of the windows, said that she will never forget the large number of injured, mostly women and children, she saw at the accident site.\n\nAnother survivor, 10 year-old Karim Abdel Wahab, said that he couldn't find his mother and brother who were traveling with him in the train.\n\nThe driver of the Cairo-Alexandria train has surrendered himself to police and has been transferred to El-Raml police station in Alexandria for investigation, local media reported, citing a health ministry official.\n\nEgypt's prosecutor-general Nabil Sadiq has ordered an urgent investigation into the collision to find out the reason behind the crash.\n\nPresident El-Sisi has expressed his condolences to the victims and ordered government bodies to follow up on developments from the deadly collision and identify the cause of the accident.\n\n\"The rescue team is currently searching for survivals while ambulances are transferring the injured to nearby hospitals,\" said Magdy Hegazi, Undersecretary at the Health Ministry.\n\nThe ministry said 75 ambulances had been deployed at the crash scene to treat casualties and that all the hospitals in Alexandria had been placed on high alert.\n\nTrain accidents are common in Egypt. In 2016, a train derailed in south of Cairo, killing five people, and injuring 27 people in the al-Ayat area.\n\nAnother train derailment in Badr Rashin in Giza killed at least 19 people in 2013.\n\nIn 2012, a collision between a train and school bus on a rail crossing in the town of Manaflut in Upper Egypt killed 51 people, mostly children.\n\nAt least 360 people were killed in 2002 in Egypt's worst train disaster when a major fire engulfed seven carriages of an overcrowded passenger train.\n\nAlso Read:\n\nEgypt train collision kills 41, injures nearly 180\n\nEgypt launches air strikes on Libya terror camps after gunmen attacked bus of Coptic Christians\n\nAlso Watch:\n\nYemen joins list of nations that have cut ties with Qatar", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T15:39:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"uri": "indiatoday.intoday.in", "title": "IndiaToday.in", "id": "930"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "15:39:00", "url": "http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/cairo-alexandria-train-collision/1/1024844.html", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8813885", "image": "http://media2.intoday.in/indiatoday/images/stories/egypt_647_081217082746.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "15:39:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

{"eng": "List of town tramway systems in Africa"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_town_tramway_systems_in_Africa", "score": 4, "id": "1396728", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "A train collision just east of the coastal city of Alexandria has killed at least 36 people, Egypt's Health Ministry said on Friday. (Aug. 11)\n\nALEXANDRIA, Egypt (AP) -- Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing 43 people, according to authorities, the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nMagdy Hegazy, a top health official in Alexandria, said that along with the 43 killed, the crash also injured 122 people.\n\nThe Egyptian Railways Authority said earlier that a train coming from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of a train that was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured.\n\nAn eyewitness who lives close to the crash site said he and others ran toward the site when they heard the sound of the impact.\n\n\"We ran to the scene and we found people jumping from the train and lots of dead,\" said Abdel-Bari Abdel-Hamid.\n\nBy nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's crash was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travelers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 -- mostly children between the ages of four and six. Two months later, at least 19 people died and more than 100 were injured in a train derailment south of Cairo.\n\n-- -- --\n\nZaki reported from Cairo.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 141, "textStart": 134}, {"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 2696, "textStart": 2683}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T20:44:00Z", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "source": {"uri": "dothaneagle.com", "title": "Dothan Eagle", "id": "11193"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:44:00", "url": "http://www.dothaneagle.com/news/ap/world/train-collision-in-northern-egypt-kills-injured/article_9c7d1105-9716-52ee-ad0f-5feef1d214bd.html", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8698085", "image": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/dothaneagle.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/d/0f/d0f6d103-e89f-5420-a2e4-7451053a2e3a/598df1cb82683.image.jpg?resize=512%2C341", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "20:44:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

least 41 dead and 179 injured, ahramonline reported quoting a Health ministry statement.\n\nThe driver of the Cairo-Alexandria train has surrendered himself to police and has been transferred to El-Raml police station in Alexandria for investigation, it said.\n\nEgypt's prosecutor-general Nabil Sadiq has ordered an urgent investigation into the collision to find out the reason behind the crash.\n\nPresident El-Sisi has expressed his condolences to the victims and ordered government bodies to follow up on developments from the deadly collision and identify the cause of the "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabic", "score": 2, "id": "1044431", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "By: PTI | Cairo | Published:August 12, 2017 8:30 am Army attend the scene of a train collision just decade. (AP Photo) 60 kids die in five days at Gorakhpur hospital, 9 the day Yogi Adityanath came visitingChina officials meet US counterparts: Cautiously, Army raises alert level in Arunachal PradeshToilet: Ek Prem Katha box office collection day 1: Akshay Kumar's film is expected to cross the Rs 10 crore mark\n\nAt least 44 people were killed and nearly 180 others injured after two trains collided near Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria, officials said. The Egyptian cabinet said in a statement that the number of deaths may increase and the final toll will be announced after clearing the debris of the two trains.\n\nThe deadly collision took place on Friday after a train travelling to Alexandria from Cairo, crashed into the back of another train coming from the Canal city of Port Said, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, east of Alexandria, the Egyptian Railways Authority said in a statement.\n\nThe area of the collision has been cordoned off by security forces as a rescue team is currently searching for survivors over the night and removing the wreckage off the tracks, it said. Iman Hamdy, 26, a survivor of the accident, said that she was travelling in the train going to Alexandria and noticed that it was already in a bad condition.\n\nThe Al-Masri el-Youm Arabic newspaper quoted her saying that the train abruptly stopped for 15 minutes in Ebies area near Khorshid station when she felt its collision with the another train. Hamdy, who succeeded in escaping from the train through one of the windows, said that she will never forget the large number of injured, mostly women and children, she saw at the accident site.\n\nAnother survivor, 10 year-old Karim Abdel Wahab, said that he couldn't find his mother and brother who were travelling with him in the train. The driver of the Cairo-Alexandria train has surrendered himself to police and has been transferred to El-Raml police station in Alexandria for investigation, local media said quoting a health ministry official.\n\nEgypt's prosecutor-general Nabil Sadiq has ordered an urgent investigation into the collision to find out the reason behind the crash. President El-Sisi has expressed his condolences to the victims and ordered government bodies to follow up on developments from the deadly collision and identify the cause of the accident.\n\n\"The rescue team is currently searching for survivals while ambulances are transferring the injured to nearby hospitals,\" said Magdy Hegazi, undersecretary at the Health ministry. The ministry said 75 ambulances had been deployed at the crash scene to treat casualties and that all the hospitals in Alexandria had been placed on high alert.\n\nTrain accidents are common in Egypt. In 2016, a train derailed in south of Cairo, killing five people, and injuring 27 people in the al-Ayat area. Another train derailment in Badr Rashin in Giza killed at least 19 people in 2013.\n\nIn 2012, a collision between a train and school bus on a rail crossing in the town of Manaflut in Upper Egypt killed 51 people, mostly children. At least 360 people were killed in 2002 in Egypt's worst train disaster when a major fire engulfed seven carriages of an overcrowded passenger train.\n\nFor all the latest World News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: Egypt Train Collision", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 43, "textStart": 28}, {"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 176, "textStart": 163}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T03:07:00Z", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "title": "The Indian Express", "id": "1155"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:07:00", "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/world/egypt-train-collision-kills-44-injures-nearly-180-4792996/", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8736268", "image": "http://images.indianexpress.com/2017/08/egy-759.jpg?w=759", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "03:07:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"1044431", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "At least 44 people were killed and nearly 180 others injured after two trains collided near Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria, officials said.\n\nThe Egyptian cabinet said in a statement that the number of deaths may increase and the final toll will be announced after clearing the debris of the two trains.\n\nThe deadly collision took place yesterday after a train travelling to Alexandria from Cairo, crashed into the back of another train coming from the Canal city of Port Said, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, east of Alexandria, the Egyptian Railways Authority said in a statement.\n\nThe area of the collision has been cordoned off by security forces as a rescue team is currently searching for survivors over the night and removing the wreckage off the tracks, it said.\n\nIman Hamdy, 26, a survivor of the accident, said that she was travelling in the train going to Alexandria and noticed that it was already in a bad condition.\n\nThe Al-Masri el-Youm Arabic newspaper quoted her saying that the train abruptly stopped for 15 minutes in Ebies area near Khorshid station when she felt its collision with the another train.\n\nHamdy, who succeeded in escaping from the train through one of the windows, said that she will never forget the large number of injured, mostly women and children, she saw at the accident site.\n\nAnother survivor, 10 year-old Karim Abdel Wahab, said that he couldn't find his mother and brother who were travelling with him in the train.\n\nThe driver of the Cairo-Alexandria train has surrendered himself to police and has been transferred to El-Raml police station in Alexandria for investigation, local media said quoting a health ministry official.\n\nEgypt's prosecutor-general Nabil Sadiq has ordered an urgent investigation into the collision to find out the reason behind the crash.\n\nPresident El-Sisi has expressed his condolences to the victims and ordered government bodies to follow up on developments from the deadly collision and identify the cause of the accident.\n\n\"The rescue team is currently searching for survivals while ambulances are transferring the injured to nearby hospitals,\" said Magdy Hegazi, undersecretary at the Health ministry.\n\nThe ministry said 75 ambulances had been deployed at the crash scene to treat casualties and that all the hospitals in Alexandria had been placed on high alert.\n\nTrain accidents are common in Egypt. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptian_National_Railways", "score": 3, "id": "634821", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Two passenger trains have collided in Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria, killing 37 people and injuring 123, a health ministry spokesman said.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi ordered authorities to establish who was responsible for the crash, which left bodies strewn on the ground around wrecked carriages.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Railways Authority said a train traveling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nState newspaper al-Ahram said earlier that 36 bodies had been taken to hospital morgues in Alexandria province.\n\nAs rescue teams pulled dead and injured from the damaged rail wagons, public prosecutor Nabil Sadek ordered an urgent investigation.\n\nA railroad switching error most likely caused the crash, a security source said without giving further details.\n\nOne resident, Hoda, was standing on her rooftop when she saw the trains collide.\n\n\"They rose in the air forming a pyramid when they collided,\" she said.\n\n\"I started to scream from the rooftops for people to grab some sheets and run.\"\n\nA health ministry spokesman said 75 ambulances had been deployed at the crash scene. Some people were still stuck inside the trains, a medical official told state TV.\n\n\"The train I was riding was going very quickly,\" said passenger Moumen Youssef.\n\n\"I found myself on the floor. When we came out, we found four train cars crushed and a lot of people on the ground.\"\n\nThis collision was the latest in a series of deadly accidents in Egypt that have claimed hundreds of lives.\n\nFigures recently released by the state's statistics agency showed that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nIn 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travellers.\n\nThe train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn 2006, at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd later in November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 people, mostly children between the ages of four and six.\n\nTwo months later, at least 19 people died and more than 100 were injured in a train derailment south of Cairo.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 2263, "textStart": 2250}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:50:00Z", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "source": {"uri": "abc.net.au", "title": "ABC News", "id": "19269"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:50:00", "url": "http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-08-12/egypt-train-crash-kills-36-injures-more-than-120/8799918", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8691043", "image": "http://www.abc.net.au/news/image/8800286-1x1-700x700.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:50:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"1044431", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "By PTI | Cairo | Posted 44 minutes agoNow Available on the mid-day iOS App, Download Now\n\nOfficials and emergency personnel remove the wreckage of a collision between two trains near Khorshid station in Alexandria. Pic/AFP\n\nAt least 44 people were killed and nearly 180 others injured after two trains collided near Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria, officials said. The Egyptian cabinet said in a statement that the number of deaths may increase and the final toll will be announced after clearing the debris of the two trains.\n\nThe deadly collision took place yesterday after a train travelling to Alexandria from Cairo, crashed into the back of another train coming from the Canal city of Port Said, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, east of Alexandria, the Egyptian Railways Authority said in a statement.\n\nThe area of the collision has been cordoned off by security forces as a rescue team is currently searching for survivors over the night and removing the wreckage off the tracks, it said. Iman Hamdy, 26, a survivor of the accident, said that she was travelling in the train going to Alexandria and noticed that it was already in a bad condition.\n\nThe Al-Masri el-Youm Arabic newspaper quoted her saying that the train abruptly stopped for 15 minutes in Ebies area near Khorshid station when she felt its collision with the another train. Hamdy, who succeeded in escaping from the train through one of the windows, said that she will never forget the large number of injured, mostly women and children, she saw at the accident site.\n\nAnother survivor, 10 year-old Karim Abdel Wahab, said that he couldn't find his mother and brother who were travelling with him in the train. The driver of the Cairo-Alexandria train has surrendered himself to police and has been transferred to El-Raml police station in Alexandria for investigation, local media said quoting a health ministry official.\n\nEgypt's prosecutor-general Nabil Sadiq has ordered an urgent investigation into the collision to find out the reason behind the crash. President El-Sisi has expressed his condolences to the victims and ordered government bodies to follow up on developments from the deadly collision and identify the cause of the accident.\n\n\"The rescue team is currently searching for survivals while ambulances are transferring the injured to nearby hospitals,\" said Magdy Hegazi, undersecretary at the Health ministry. The ministry said 75 ambulances had been deployed at the crash scene to treat casualties and that all the hospitals in Alexandria had been placed on high alert.\n\nTrain accidents are common in Egypt. In 2016, a train derailed in south of Cairo, killing five people, and injuring 27 people in the al-Ayat area. Another train derailment in Badr Rashin in Giza killed at least 19 people in 2013. In 2012, a collision between a train and school bus on a rail crossing in the town of Manaflut in Upper Egypt killed 51 people, mostly children.\n\nAt least 360 people were killed in 2002 in Egypt's worst train disaster when a major fire engulfed seven carriages of an overcrowded passenger train.\n\nTrending Video\n\nWatch Video: Youngsters fall to their death at Amboli Ghat\n\nDownload the new mid-day android app to get updates on all the latest and trending stories on the go https://goo.gl/8Xlcvr", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T07:38:00Z", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "source": {"uri": "mid-day.com", "title": "mid-day", "id": "2837"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:38:00", "url": "http://www.mid-day.com/articles/egypt-train-collision-kills-44-injures-nearly-180/18500196", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8759185", "image": "http://images.mid-day.com/images/2017/aug/Train-accident-l.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "07:38:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Alexandria on Friday as investigations began.\n\nCAIRO - Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing at least 40 people, according to the Health Ministry, in the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nThe ministry said the crash also left 123 people injured.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Railways Authority said that one of the trains, traveling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the official statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nSome officials who spoke on condition of anonymity said that early indications suggested that one of the trains had a mechanical failure and stalled, causing the second train to strike it.\n\nFootage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\n\"The train I was riding was going very quickly,\" passenger Moumen Youssef told Reuters. \"I found myself on the floor. When we came out, we found four train cars crushed and a lot of people on the ground.\"\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, east of Alexandria, the Egyptian Railways Authority said in a statement.\n\nThe area of the collision has been cordoned off by security forces as a rescue team is currently searching for survivors over the night and removing the wreckage off the tracks, it said.\n\nIman Hamdy, 26, a survivor of the accident, said that she was travelling in the train going to Alexandria and noticed that it was already in a bad condition.\n\nThe Al-Masri el-Youm Arabic newspaper quoted her saying that the train abruptly stopped for 15 minutes in Ebies area near Khorshid station when she felt its collision with the another train.\n\nHamdy, who succeeded in escaping from the train through one of the windows, said that she will never forget the large number of injured, mostly women and children, she saw at the accident site.\n\nAnother survivor, 10 year-old Karim Abdel Wahab, said that he couldn't find his mother and brother who were travelling with him in the train.\n\nThe driver of the Cairo-Alexandria train has surrendered himself to police and has been transferred to El-Raml police station in Alexandria for investigation, local media said quoting a health ministry official.\n\nEgypt's prosecutor-general Nabil Sadiq has ordered an urgent investigation into the collision to find out the reason behind the crash.\n\nPresident El-Sisi has expressed his condolences to the victims and ordered government bodies to follow up on developments from the deadly collision and identify the cause of the accident.\n\n\"The rescue team is currently searching for survivals while ambulances are transferring the injured to nearby hospitals,\" said Magdy Hegazi, undersecretary at the Health ministry.\n\nThe ministry said 75 ambulances had been deployed at the crash scene to treat casualties and that all the hospitals in Alexandria had been placed on high alert.\n\nTrain accidents are common in Egypt. In 2016, a train derailed in south of Cairo, killing five people, and injuring 27 people in the al-Ayat area.\n\nAnother train derailment in Badr Rashin in Giza killed at least 19 people in 2013.\n\nIn 2012, a collision between a train and school bus on a rail crossing in the town of Manaflut in Upper Egypt killed 51 people, mostly children.\n\nAt least 360 people were killed in 2002 in Egypt's worst train disaster when a major fire engulfed seven carriages of an overcrowded passenger train.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:28:00Z", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "source": {"uri": "business-standard.com", "title": "Business Standard", "id": "405"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:28:00", "url": "http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/egypt-train-collision-kills-44-injures-nearly-180-117081200074_1.html", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8729301", "image": "http://bsmedia.business-standard.com/_media/bs/img/common/no_preview.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Glendale_train_crash", "score": 2, "id": "1169734", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Alexandria: Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing 43 people, according to authorities, the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nMagdy Hegazy, a top health official in Alexandria, said that along with the 43 killed, the crash also injured 122 people.\n\nThe Egyptian Railways Authority said earlier that a train coming from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of a train that was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured.\n\nAn eyewitness who lives close to the crash site said he and others ran toward the site when they heard the sound of the impact.\n\n\"We ran to the scene and we found people jumping from the train and lots of dead,\" said Abdel-Bari Abdel-Hamid.\n\nBy nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's crash was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travelers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 - mostly children between the ages of four and six. crash"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Glendale_train_crash", "score": 2, "id": "1169734", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "CAIRO -- Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing at least 36 people and injuring about 123, according to the Health Ministry, in the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Railways Authority said a train travelling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, saying only that the authority's experts would be investigating.\n\nAssociated Press video footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's collision was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travellers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 -- mostly children between the ages of four and six. Two months later, at least 19 people died and more than 100 were injured in a train derailment south of Cairo.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 1863, "textStart": 1850}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T15:42:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "title": "CTV News", "id": "30"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "17:06:00", "url": "http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/train-collision-near-egypt-s-alexandria-kills-36-injures-123-1.3541807", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8666753", "image": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/polopoly_fs/1.840156.1449217654!/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/landscape_620/image.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "15:42:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Alexandria, killing at least 40 people and injuring more than 100.\n\nIt is the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Railways Authority said a train travelling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, saying only that the authority's experts would be investigating.\n\nVideo footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's collision was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years.\n\nFigures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached crash"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Glendale_train_crash", "score": 2, "id": "1169734", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "CAIRO (AP) - Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing at least 36 people and injuring about 123, according to the Health Ministry, in the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Railways Authority said a train traveling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, saying only that the authority's experts would be investigating.\n\nAssociated Press video footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's collision was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travelers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 - mostly children between the ages of four and six. Two months later, at least 19 people died and more than 100 were injured in a train derailment south of Cairo.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Level_crossing", "score": 1, "id": "325180", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sleeping while on duty"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sleeping_while_on_duty", "score": 2, "id": "565131", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Egyptians search for survivors at the site of a crash where two trains collided near the Khorshid station in Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria, Egypt August 11, 2017. -- Reuters picALEXANDRIA, Aug 12 -- At least 37 people were killed as two trains collided yesterday outside the Mediterranean city of Alexandria, in one of the deadliest in a string of such accidents in Egypt, the health ministry said.\n\nThe crash also injured 123 people, the ministry said in a statement.\n\nFootage on the state broadcaster showed one train had partly keeled over in the crash, and medics were seen moving the dead and injured to ambulances.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, said the crash was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt on the rails.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne train had been heading from Cairo to the northern city of Alexandria and the other from the canal city of Port Said, east of the capital, to Alexandria.\n\nThe dead and injured were initially placed on blankets in a field beside the tracks running through farmland on the outskirts of the city.\n\nThe health ministry said 75 ambulances had been dispatched to treat casualties and that all the hospitals in Alexandria had been placed on high alert.\n\nAssistant health minister Sharif Wadi told state television that most of the injured had been transferred to hospital.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster, his office said.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident had jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nString of accidents\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the busy rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwest Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into bus, truck and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nIn August 2006, at least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, a court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died when a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital. -- AFP", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Glendale_train_crash", "score": 2, "id": "1169734", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "CAIRO -- Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing 43 people, according to authorities, the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nMagdy Hegazy, a top health official in Alexandria, said that along with the 43 killed, the crash also injured 122 people.\n\nThe Egyptian Railways Authority said earlier that a train coming from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of a train that was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured.\n\nAn eyewitness who lives close to the crash site said he and others ran toward the site when they heard the sound of the impact.\n\n\"We ran to the scene and we found people jumping from the train and lots of dead,\" said Abdel-Bari Abdel-Hamid.\n\nBy nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's crash was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travelers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 -- mostly children between the ages of four and six. Two months later, at least 19 people died and more than 100 were injured in a train derailment south of Cairo.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 2535, "textStart": 2522}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T03:11:00Z", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "source": {"uri": "dentonrc.com", "title": "dentonrc.com", "id": "2278"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:11:00", "url": "http://www.dentonrc.com/news/nation-and-world/2017/08/11/train-collision-northern-egypt-kills-43-122-injured", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8736719", "image": "https://dentonrc.imgix.net/1502507344-AFP_RH92D.jpg?w=1200&h=630&format=jpg&crop=faces&fit=crop", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "03:11:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

while on duty"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sleeping_while_on_duty", "score": 2, "id": "565131", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Alexandria Governorate: The death toll from Egypt's latest train disaster rose to 41 on Saturday as two drivers were questioned and cranes worked to clear the stricken railway line between Cairo and the Mediterranean city of Alexandria.\n\nThe drivers of the two trains that collided on Friday have been held for questioning and four railway officials suspended pending the results of a probe into its causes, Transportation Minister Hisham Arafat told an Egyptian broadcaster.\n\nUnder floodlights, rescue teams had combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nArafat had told reporters at the scene of the accident that it was not yet clear why the train had stopped, but suggested old traffic signals were to blame.\n\n\"We have a big problem we had already announced, which is old traffic signals. We are completely overhauling them. This section here is being developed,\" he said.\n\nAn injured passenger who was on the stationary train said its departure had been delayed and that it kept stopping en route.\n\n\"It stopped every now and then between stations or before stations for five minutes, I don't know why,\" the man told Dream television station from his hospital bed.\n\n\"Everyone was scattered (by the collision), bodies were flung around,\" he said.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when the two trains collided near Alexandria rose to 41 dead, the health ministry said on Saturday.\n\nThe accident also wounded 132 people, with 79 being discharged after treatment while 53 remained in hospital on Saturday, Health Minister Ahmed Emad el-Din Rady said.\n\nA stream of ambulances had ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on Egypt's heavily-used rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwestern Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into a bus, a lorry and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nAt least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in August 2006 in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, a court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died as a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 2460, "textStart": 2447}, {"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 3303, "textStart": 3294}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 3577, "textStart": 3566}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T13:51:00Z", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "source": {"uri": "zeenews.india.com", "title": "Zee News", "id": "1741"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:51:00", "url": "http://zeenews.india.com/world/egypt-train-crash-toll-hits-41-as-drivers-questioned-2032435.html", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8799742", "image": "http://ste.india.com/sites/default/files/default_images/zee-nopic_2.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "13:51:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

outside the Mediterranean city of Alexandria, in one of the deadliest in a string of such accidents in Egypt, the health ministry said.\n\nThe crash also injured 123 people, the ministry said in a statement.\n\nFootage on the state broadcaster showed one train had partly keeled over in the crash, and medics were seen moving the dead and injured to ambulances.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, said the crash was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt on the rails. The other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne of them had been heading from Cairo to the northern city of Alexandria and the other from the canal city of Port Said, east of the capital, to Alexandria.\n\nThe dead and injured were initially placed on blankets by the sides of the tracks amid farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria.\n\nAssistant health minister Sharif Wadi told state television that most of the injured had been taken to hospital.\n\nEgypt's transport minister has ordered an investigation into the crash, pledging to \"hold accountable\" whoever was responsible, state television reported.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident had jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Months later a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAlmost a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of Cairo.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the busy rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwest Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into bus, truck and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nIn August 2006, at least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 wounded in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, an Egyptian court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died as a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 1328, "textStart": 1315}, {"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 2151, "textStart": 2142}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 2368, "textStart": 2357}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T17:45:00Z", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "source": {"uri": "news24.com", "title": "news24", "id": "309"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "17:45:00", "url": "http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/pictures-egypt-train-collision-death-toll-rises-to-36-ministry-20170811", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8673123", "image": "http://cdn.24.co.za/files/Cms/General/d/758/446b0cc488d946b4b3594d03d72a5da3.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "17:45:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabic", "score": 3, "id": "1044431", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Cairo, At least 44 people were killed and nearly 180 others injured after two trains collided near Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria, officials said. The Egyptian cabinet said in a statement that the number of deaths may increase and the final toll will be announced after clearing the debris of the two trains.\n\nThe deadly collision took place yesterday after a train travelling to Alexandria from Cairo, crashed into the back of another train coming from the Canal city of Port Said, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, east of Alexandria, the Egyptian Railways Authority said in a statement.\n\nThe area of the collision has been cordoned off by security forces as a rescue team is currently searching for survivors over the night and removing the wreckage off the tracks, it said. Iman Hamdy, 26, a survivor of the accident, said that she was travelling in the train going to Alexandria and noticed that it was already in a bad condition.The Al-Masri el-Youm Arabic newspaper quoted her saying that the train abruptly stopped for 15 minutes in Ebies area near Khorshid station when she felt its collision with the another train.\n\nHamdy, who succeeded in escaping from the train through one of the windows, said that she will never forget the large number of injured, mostly women and children, she saw at the accident site. Another survivor, 10 year-old Karim Abdel Wahab, said that he couldn't find his mother and brother who were travelling with him in the train. The driver of the Cairo-Alexandria train has surrendered himself to police and has been transferred to El-Raml police station in Alexandria for investigation, local media said quoting a health ministry official.\n\nEgypt's prosecutor-general Nabil Sadiq has ordered an urgent investigation into the collision to find out the reason behind the crash. President El-Sisi has expressed his condolences to the victims and ordered government bodies to follow up on developments from the deadly collision and identify the cause of the accident.\n\n\"The rescue team is currently searching for survivals while ambulances are transferring the injured to nearby hospitals,\" said Magdy Hegazi, undersecretary at the Health ministry.\"The rescue team is currently searching for survivals while ambulances are transferring the injured to nearby hospitals,\" said Magdy Hegazi, undersecretary at the Health ministry. The ministry said 75 ambulances had been deployed at the crash scene to treat casualties and that all the hospitals in Alexandria had been placed on high alert. Train accidents are common in Egypt. In 2016, a train derailed in south of Cairo, killing five people, and injuring 27 people in the al-Ayat area.\n\nAnother train derailment in Badr Rashin in Giza killed at least 19 people in 2013. In 2012, a collision between a train and school bus on a rail crossing in the town of Manaflut in Upper Egypt killed 51 people, mostly children.Another train derailment in Badr Rashin in Giza killed at least 19 people in 2013. In 2012, a collision between a train and school bus on a rail crossing in the town of Manaflut in Upper Egypt killed 51 people, mostly children.
