"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Glendale_train_crash", "score": 2, "id": "1169734", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "ALEXANDRIA, Egypt (AP) -- Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing 43 people, according to authorities, the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nMagdy Hegazy, a top health official in Alexandria, said that along with the 43 killed, the crash also injured 122 people.\n\nThe Egyptian Railways Authority said earlier that a train coming from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of a train that was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured.\n\nAn eyewitness who lives close to the crash site said he and others ran toward the site when they heard the sound of the impact.\n\n\"We ran to the scene and we found people jumping from the train and lots of dead,\" said Abdel-Bari Abdel-Hamid.\n\nBy nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's crash was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travelers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 -- mostly children between the ages of four and six. while on duty"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sleeping_while_on_duty", "score": 2, "id": "565131", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "ALEXANDRIA: The death toll from Egypt's latest train disaster rose to 41 on Saturday as two drivers were questioned and cranes worked to clear the stricken railway line between Cairo and the Mediterranean city of Alexandria.\n\nThe drivers of the two trains that collided on Friday have been held for questioning and four railway officials suspended pending the results of a probe into its causes, Transportation Minister Hisham Arafat told an Egyptian broadcaster.\n\nUnder floodlights, rescue teams had combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nArafat had told reporters at the scene of the accident that it was not yet clear why the train had stopped, but suggested old traffic signals were to blame.\n\n\"We have a big problem we had already announced, which is old traffic signals. We are completely overhauling them. This section here is being developed,\" he said.\n\nAn injured passenger who was on the stationary train said its departure had been delayed and that it kept stopping en route.\n\n\"It stopped every now and then between stations or before stations for five minutes, I don't know why,\" the man told Dream television station from his hospital bed.\n\n\"Everyone was scattered (by the collision), bodies were flung around,\" he said.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when the two trains collided near Alexandria rose to 41 dead, the health ministry said on Saturday.\n\nThe accident also wounded 132 people, with 79 being discharged after treatment while 53 remained in hospital on Saturday, Health Minister Ahmed Emad El-Din Rady said.\n\nA stream of ambulances had ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah El-Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train plowed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train plowed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on Egypt's heavily-used rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwestern Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into a bus, a lorry and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nAt least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in August 2006 in a collision between two trains traveling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, a court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died as a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 2446, "textStart": 2433}, {"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 3287, "textStart": 3278}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 3561, "textStart": 3550}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T21:09:00Z", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "source": {"uri": "arabnews.com", "title": "Arab News", "id": "4355"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "21:09:00", "url": "http://www.arabnews.com/node/1143696/middle-east", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8843949", "image": "http://www.arabnews.com/sites/default/files/2017/08/12/969321-1300363340.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "21:09:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"dmoz/Business/Education and Training/Health and Safety", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Education_and_Training/Health_and_Safety", "wgt": 100, "id": 1527}], "uri": "708032755", "lang": "eng", "title": "Train collision in northern Egypt kills at least 36", "concepts": [], "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/article36023283.ece/0d2d5/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-fbb55b0e-7d2f-4c86-887f-ebbb8c6f5769_I1.jpg\n\nTwo passenger trains have collided just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing at least 36 people and injuring about 123, according to the Health Ministry.\n\nIt is the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Railways Authority said a train travelling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, saying only that the authority's experts would be investigating.\n\nVideo footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's collision was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years.\n\nFigures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travellers.\n\nThe train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their nursery in the country's south, killing more than 50 - mostly children between the ages of four and six.\n\nTwo months later, at least 19 people died and more than 100 were injured in a train derailment south of Cairo.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": FRANCE PRESSE, Cairo, Egypt, Aug 11 - At least 36 people were killed as two trains collided Friday outside the Mediterranean city of Alexandria, in one of the deadliest in a string of such accidents in Egypt, the health ministry said.\n\nThe crash also injured 123 people, the ministry said in a statement.\n\nFootage on the state broadcaster showed one train had partly keeled over in the crash, and medics were seen moving the dead and injured to ambulances.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, said the crash was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt on the rails. The other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne of them had been heading from Cairo to the northern city of Alexandria and the other from the canal city of Port Said, east of the capital, to Alexandria.\n\nThe dead and injured were initially placed on blankets by the sides of the tracks amid farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria.\n\nAssistant health minister Sharif Wadi told state television that most of the injured had been taken to hospital.\n\nEgypt's transport minister has ordered an investigation into the crash, pledging to \"hold accountable\" whoever was responsible, state television reported.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident had jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Months later a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAlmost a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of Cairo.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the busy rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwest Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into bus, truck and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nIn August 2006, at least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 wounded in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, an Egyptian court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest city of Alexandria.\n\nThe drivers of the two trains that collided on Friday have been held for questioning and four railway officials suspended pending the results of a probe into its causes, Transportation Minister Hisham Arafat told an Egyptian broadcaster.\n\nUnder floodlights, rescue teams had combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it. Arafat had told reporters at the scene of the accident that it was not yet clear why the train had stopped, but suggested old traffic signals were to blame.\n\n\"We have a big problem we had already announced, which is old traffic signals. We are completely overhauling them. This section here is being developed,\" he said.\n\nAn injured passenger who was on the stationary train said its departure had been delayed and that it kept stopping en route.\n\n\"It stopped every now and then between stations or before stations for five minutes, I don't know why,\" the man told Dream television station from his hospital bed.\n\n\"Everyone was scattered (by the collision), bodies were flung around,\" he said.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when the two trains collided near Alexandria rose to 41 dead, the health ministry said on Saturday.\n\nThe accident also wounded 132 people, with 79 being discharged after treatment while 53 remained in hospital on Saturday, Health Minister Ahmed Emad el-Din Rady said.\n\nA stream of ambulances had ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line. One train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Glendale_train_crash", "score": 2, "id": "1169734", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "ALEXANDRIA, Egypt (AP) \u00e2\u0080\" Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing at least 40 people, according to the Health Ministry, in the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nThe ministry said the crash also left 123 people injured.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Railways Authority said one of the trains, traveling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured.\n\nAn eyewitness who lives close to the crash site said he and others ran toward the site when they heard the sound of the impact.\n\n\"We ran to the scene and we found people jumping from the train and lots of dead,\" said Abdel-Bari Abdel-Hamid.\n\nBy nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's crash was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travelers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 \u00e2\u0080\" mostly children between the ages of four and six. collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing at least 40 people, according to the Health Ministry, in the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nThe ministry said the crash also left 123 people injured.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Railways Authority said one of the trains, travelling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured.\n\nAn eyewitness who lives close to the crash site said he and others ran toward the site when they heard the sound of the impact.\n\n\"We ran to the scene and we found people jumping from the train and lots of dead,\" said Abdel-Bari Abdel-Hamid.\n\nBy nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's crash was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travellers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 -- mostly children between the ages of four and six. "id": "306793", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "North Africa"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Africa", "score": 2, "id": "309042", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Canal"}, "uri": {"label": {"eng": "Mediterranean Sea"}, "type": "loc", "score": 4, "location": null, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea", "id": "313896"}, {"label": {"eng": "Egyptians"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptians", "score": 2, "id": "324947", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Level crossing"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Level_crossing", "score": 2, "id": "325180", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Railway signal"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Railway_signal", "score": 2, "id": "339824", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sleeping while on duty"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sleeping_while_on_duty", "score": 2, "id": "565131", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "CAIRO -- At least 36 people were killed as two trains collided Friday outside the Mediterranean city of Alexandria, in one of the deadliest in a string of such accidents in Egypt, the health ministry said.\n\nThe crash also injured 123 people, the ministry said in a statement. Footage on the state broadcaster showed one train had partly keeled over in the crash, and medics were seen moving the dead and injured to ambulances.\n\nTransport Ministry officials, quoted on state television, said the crash was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt on the rails. The other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne of them had been heading from Cairo to the northern city of Alexandria and the other from the canal city of Port Said, east of the capital, to Alexandria. The dead and injured were initially placed on blankets by the sides of the tracks amid farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria.\n\nAssistant Health Minister Sharif Wadi told state television that most of the injured had been taken to hospital. Egypt's transport minister has ordered an investigation into the crash, pledging to \"hold accountable\" whoever was responsible, state television reported.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train plowed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people. That accident had jolted the government, which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority. The accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Months later a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people. Almost a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of Cairo. They had been returning from a wedding when the train plowed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines. There have been many other fatal crashes on the busy rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwest Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into bus, truck and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train. In August 2006, at least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 wounded in a collision between two trains traveling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, an Egyptian court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect. "score": 2, "id": "565131", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Alexandria: At least 36 people were killed as two trains collided Friday outside the Mediterranean city of Alexandria, in one of the deadliest in a string of such accidents in Egypt, the health ministry said.\n\nThe crash also injured 123 people, the ministry said in a statement.\n\nFootage on the state broadcaster showed one train had partly keeled over in the crash, and medics were seen moving the dead and injured to ambulances.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, said the crash was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt on the rails. The other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne of them had been heading from Cairo to the northern city of Alexandria and the other from the canal city of Port Said, east of the capital, to Alexandria.\n\nThe dead and injured were initially placed on blankets by the sides of the tracks running through farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria.\n\nAssistant health minister Sharif Wadi told state television that most of the injured had been taken to hospital.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster, his office said.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident had jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing 43 people, according to authorities, the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nMagdy Hegazy, a top health official in Alexandria, said that along with the 43 killed, the crash also injured 122 people.\n\nThe Egyptian Railways Authority said earlier that a train coming from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of a train that was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured.\n\nAn eyewitness who lives close to the crash site said he and others ran toward the site when they heard the sound of the impact.\n\n\"We ran to the scene and we found people jumping from the train and lots of dead,\" said Abdel-Bari Abdel-Hamid.\n\nBy nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's crash was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travelers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 -- mostly children between the ages of four and six. Two months later, at least 19 people died and more than 100 were injured in a train derailment south of Cairo.\n\nZaki reported from Cairo.\n\nNever miss another Facebook post from WISH-TV", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 2552, "textStart": 2539}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T21:32:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"uri": "wishtv.com", "title": "WISH-TV", "id": "3130"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "21:32:00", "url": "http://wishtv.com/2017/08/11/train-collision-in-egypt-kills-43-122-injured/", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8705064", "image": "https://lintvwish.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/egypt-train-collision.jpg?w=640", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "21:32:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

phones.\n\nThe toll from yesterday's accident when two trains hurtled into each other near Alexandria has risen to 40 dead and 123 wounded, said health ministry spokesman Khaled Moujahed, as local media said the number of fatalities was likely to rise.\n\nA stream of ambulances ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria "Shalimar Express"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shalimar_Express", "score": 2, "id": "1354200", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "CAIRO: At least 36 people were killed as two trains collided on Friday outside the Mediterranean city of Alexandria, in one of the deadliest in a string of such accidents in Egypt, the health ministry said.\n\nThe crash also injured 123 people, the ministry said in a statement.\n\nFootage on the state broadcaster showed one train had partly keeled over in the crash, and medics were seen moving the dead and injured to ambulances.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, said the crash was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt on the rails. The other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne of them had been heading from Cairo to the northern city of Alexandria and the other from the canal city of Port Said, east of the capital, to Alexandria.\n\nDeadly India train accident kills over 100\n\nThe dead and injured were initially placed on blankets by the sides of the tracks amid farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria.\n\nAssistant health minister Sharif Wadi told state television that most of the injured had been taken to hospital.\n\nEgypt's transport minister has ordered an investigation into the crash, pledging to \"hold accountable\" whoever was responsible, state television reported.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nShalimar Express wreck: Death toll from train crash rises to three\n\nThat accident had jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Months later a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAlmost a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of Cairo.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the busy rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwest Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into bus, truck and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nIn August 2006, at least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 wounded in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, an Egyptian court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died as a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 1374, "textStart": 1361}, {"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 2265, "textStart": 2256}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 2482, "textStart": 2471}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T17:46:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"uri": "tribune.com.pk", "title": "The Express Tribune", "id": "1929"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "17:46:00", "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/1479307/egypt-train-collision-claims-least-36-lives/", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8673305", "image": "https://c.tribune.com.pk/2017/08/1479307-egypttraincollisionafp-1502472675-829-640x480.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "17:46:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

cranes worked Saturday to clear the stricken railway line between Cairo and the Mediterranean city of Alexandria.\n\nUnder floodlights, rescue teams had combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties, also using torches on their mobile phones.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when two trains collided near Alexandria rose to 41 dead and 179 wounded, the health ministry said on Saturday.\n\nForty-seven of the wounded have been discharged from hospital while 12 remained in intensive care, it said in a statement.\n\nA stream of ambulances had ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdul Fattah Al Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the heavily-used rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwestern Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into a bus, a lorry and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nAt least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in August 2006 in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, a court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died as a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 1490, "textStart": 1477}, {"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 2329, "textStart": 2320}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 2603, "textStart": 2592}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T13:32:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"uri": "gulfnews.com", "title": "GULF NEWS", "id": "3935"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:32:00", "url": "http://gulfnews.com/news/mena/egypt/egypt-train-crash-toll-hits-41-as-cranes-clear-busy-link-1.2072795", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8797673", "image": "http://static.gulfnews.com/polopoly_fs/1.2072794!/image/2341830149.jpg_gen/derivatives/box_460346/2341830149.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "13:32:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

between two trains on August 11, 2017 near the Mediterranean city of Alexandria that killed at least 40 people\n\nThe death toll from Egypt's latest train disaster rose to 40 as cranes worked Saturday to clear the stricken railway line between Cairo and the Mediterranean city of Alexandria.\n\nUnder floodlights, rescue teams combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties, also using torches on their mobile phones.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when two trains hurtled into each other near Alexandria has risen to 40 dead and 123 wounded, said health ministry spokesman Khaled Moujahed, as local media said the number of fatalities was likely to rise.\n\nA stream of ambulances ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nEgyptian emergency workers search the wreckage of a train collision on August 11, 2017 near the city in Alexandria that cost at least 40 lives\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the busy rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwestern Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into a bus, a lorry and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nAt least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in August 2006 in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, a court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died when a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 108, "textStart": 93, "freq": 2}, {"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 1768, "textStart": 1755}, {"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 2599, "textStart": 2590}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 2873, "textStart": 2862}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T09:42:00Z", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "title": "Mail Online", "id": "214"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:42:00", "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4784200/index.html", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8772499", "image": "http://i.dailymail.co.uk/1/2017/08/12/10/wire-1121385-1502530499-633_636x382.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "09:42:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

disaster rose to 41 as cranes worked on Saturday to clear the stricken railway line between Cairo and the Mediterranean city of Alexandria.\n\nUnder floodlights, rescue teams had combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties, also using torches on their mobile phones.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when two trains collided near Alexandria rose to 41 dead, the health ministry said on Saturday.\n\nThe accident also wounded 132 people, with 79 being discharged after treatment while 53 remained in hospital on Saturday, Health Minister Ahmed Emad El Din Rady said in a statement.\n\nA stream of ambulances had ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah Al Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the heavily-used rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwestern Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into a bus, a lorry and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nAt least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in August 2006 in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, a court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died as a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 1529, "textStart": 1516}, {"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 2368, "textStart": 2359}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 2642, "textStart": 2631}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T13:06:00Z", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "source": {"uri": "gdnonline.com", "title": "gdnonline.com", "id": "4160"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:06:00", "url": "http://www.gdnonline.com/Details/249326/Egypt-train-crash-toll-hits-41-as-cranes-clear-busy-link", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8794902", "image": "http://www.gdnonline.com/gdnimages/20170812\\20170812_145116_0.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "13:06:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Glendale_train_crash", "score": 2, "id": "1169734", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing 43 people, according to authorities, the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nMagdy Hegazy, a top health official in Alexandria, said that along with the 43 killed, the crash also injured 122 people.\n\nThe Egyptian Railways Authority said earlier that a train coming from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of a train that was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured.\n\nAn eyewitness who lives close to the crash site said he and others ran toward the site when they heard the sound of the impact.\n\n\"We ran to the scene and we found people jumping from the train and lots of dead,\" said Abdel-Bari Abdel-Hamid.\n\nBy nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's crash was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travellers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 -- mostly children between the ages of four and six. Two months later, at least 19 people died and more than 100 were injured in a train derailment south of Cairo.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 2527, "textStart": 2514}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T20:26:00Z", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "title": "The Globe and Mail", "id": "1409"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:26:00", "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/egypt-train-collision-kills-at-least-43-injures-122/article35959627/", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8695850", "image": "https://static.theglobeandmail.ca/633/news/world/article35961721.ece/ALTERNATES/w620/web-egypt-train11nw1.JPG", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "20:26:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Glendale_train_crash", "score": 2, "id": "1169734", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "ALEXANDRIA, Egypt (AP) - Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing 43 people, according to authorities, the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nMagdy Hegazy, a top health official in Alexandria, said that along with the 43 killed, the crash also injured 122 people.\n\nThe Egyptian Railways Authority said earlier that a train coming from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of a train that was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured.\n\nAn eyewitness who lives close to the crash site said he and others ran toward the site when they heard the sound of the impact.\n\n\"We ran to the scene and we found people jumping from the train and lots of dead,\" said Abdel-Bari Abdel-Hamid.\n\nBy nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's crash was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travelers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 - mostly children between the ages of four and six. Two months later, at least 19 people died and more than 100 were injured in a train derailment south of Cairo.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Glendale_train_crash", "score": 2, "id": "1169734", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "ALEXANDRIA, Egypt (AP) -- Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing 43 people, according to authorities, the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nMagdy Hegazy, a top health official in Alexandria, said that along with the 43 killed, the crash also injured 122 people.\n\nThe Egyptian Railways Authority said earlier that a train coming from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of a train that was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured.\n\nAn eyewitness who lives close to the crash site said he and others ran toward the site when they heard the sound of the impact.\n\n\"We ran to the scene and we found people jumping from the train and lots of dead,\" said Abdel-Bari Abdel-Hamid.\n\nBy nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's crash was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travelers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 -- mostly children between the ages of four and six. Mohammed Wagdy And Menna Zaki, The Associated Press on August 11, 2017.\n\nALEXANDRIA, Egypt - Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing at least 40 people, according to the Health Ministry, in the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nThe ministry said the crash also left 123 people injured.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Railways Authority said one of the trains, travelling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured.\n\nAn eyewitness who lives close to the crash site said he and others ran toward the site when they heard the sound of the impact.\n\n\"We ran to the scene and we found people jumping from the train and lots of dead,\" said Abdel-Bari Abdel-Hamid.\n\nBy nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's crash was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travellers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 - mostly children between the ages of four and six. on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing at least 40 people, according to the Health Ministry, in the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nThe ministry said the crash also left 123 people injured.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Railways Authority said one of the trains, traveling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both Mohammed Wagdy And Menna Zaki, The Associated Press on August 11, 2017.\n\nALEXANDRIA, Egypt - Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing 43 people, according to authorities, the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nMagdy Hegazy, a top health official in Alexandria, said that along with the 43 killed, the crash also injured 122 people.\n\nThe Egyptian Railways Authority said earlier that a train coming from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of a train that was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured.\n\nAn eyewitness who lives close to the crash site said he and others ran toward the site when they heard the sound of the impact.\n\n\"We ran to the scene and we found people jumping from the train and lots of dead,\" said Abdel-Bari Abdel-Hamid.\n\nBy nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's crash was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.\n\nAnd earlier, in 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travellers. The train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.\n\nIn November 2012, a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying Egyptian children to their kindergarten in the country's south, killing more than 50 - mostly children between the ages of four and six. disaster rose to 40 as cranes worked Saturday to clear the stricken railway line between Cairo and the Mediterranean city of Alexandria.\n\nUnder floodlights, rescue teams combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties, also using torches on their mobile phones.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when two trains hurtled into each other near Alexandria has risen to 40 dead and 123 wounded, said health ministry spokesman Khaled Moujahed, as local media said the number of fatalities was likely to rise.\n\nThe crash on the route to Cairo, derailed the engine of one train and two cars of the other, the Egyptian Railway Authority said.\n\nA railroad switching error was the most likely cause of the collision, according to a security source.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the busy rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwestern Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into a bus, a lorry and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nAt least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in August 2006 in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, a court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died when a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, Health officials fear that the death toll may rise further.\n\nThe two trains collided head on -- one was coming from the capital of Cairo, to the south of Alexandria, and the other was coming from the city of Port Said, located on the northern tip of the Suez Canal. Egypt's transport minister ordered an investigation into the crash, pledging to \"hold accountable\" whoever was responsible.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management. This is the deadliest train accident in the country since a November 2013 collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of Cairo. to 41 on Saturday as two drivers were questioned and cranes worked to clear the stricken railway line between Cairo and the Mediterranean city of Alexandria.\n\nThe drivers of the two trains that collided on Friday have been held for questioning and four railway officials suspended pending the results of a probe into its causes, Transportation Minister Hisham Arafat told an Egyptian broadcaster.\n\nUnder floodlights, rescue teams had combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nArafat had told reporters at the scene of the accident that it was not yet clear why the train had stopped, but suggested old traffic signals were to blame.\n\n\"We have a big problem we had already announced, which is old traffic signals. We are completely overhauling them. This section here is being developed,\" he said.\n\nAn injured passenger who was on the stationary train said its departure had been delayed and that it kept stopping en route.\n\n\"It stopped every now and then between stations or before stations for five minutes, I don't know why,\" the man told Dream television station from his hospital bed.\n\n\"Everyone was scattered (by the collision), bodies were flung around,\" he said.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when the two trains collided near Alexandria rose to 41 dead, the health ministry said on Saturday.\n\nThe accident also wounded 132 people, with 79 being discharged after treatment while 53 remained in hospital on Saturday, Health Minister Ahmed Emad el Din Rady said.\n\nA stream of ambulances had ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job. deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nALEXANDRIA: The death toll from Egypt's latest train disaster rose to 41 on Saturday as two drivers were questioned and cranes worked to clear the stricken railway line between Cairo and the Mediterranean city of Alexandria.\n\nThe drivers of the two trains that collided on Friday have been held for questioning and four railway officials suspended pending the results of a probe into its causes, Transportation Minister Hisham Arafat told an Egyptian broadcaster.\n\nUnder floodlights, rescue teams had combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nArafat had told reporters at the scene of the accident that it was not yet clear why the train had stopped, but suggested old traffic signals were to blame.\n\n\"We have a big problem we had already announced, which is old traffic signals. We are completely overhauling them. This section here is being developed,\" he said.\n\nAn injured passenger who was on the stationary train said its departure had been delayed and that it kept stopping en route.\n\n\"It stopped every now and then between stations or before stations for five minutes, I don't know why,\" the man told Dream television station from his hospital bed.\n\n\"Everyone was scattered (by the collision), bodies were flung around,\" he said.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when the two trains collided near Alexandria rose to 41 dead, the health ministry said on Saturday.\n\nThe accident also wounded 132 people, with 79 being discharged after treatment while 53 remained in hospital on Saturday, Health Minister Ahmed Emad el-Din Rady said.\n\nA stream of ambulances had ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nChronic transport problems\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on Egypt's heavily-used rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwestern Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into a bus, a lorry and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nAt least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in August 2006 in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, a court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died as a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 2630, "textStart": 2617}, {"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 3473, "textStart": 3464}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 3747, "textStart": 3736}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T22:08:00Z", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "source": {"uri": "freemalaysiatoday.com", "title": "Free Malaysia Today", "id": "10786"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:08:00", "url": "http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/world/2017/08/13/egypt-train-crash-toll-hits-41-as-drivers-questioned/", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8848706", "image": "http://s3media.freemalaysiatoday.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Egypt-train.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "22:08:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

a train travelling to Alexandria from Cairo crashed into the back of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe statement did not specify what caused the accident, saying only that the authority's experts would be investigating.\n\nVideo footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks as hundreds of onlookers railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nYesterday's collision was the latest in a series of deadly accidents which have claimed hundreds of lives over the years.\n\nFigures recently released by the State's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail incident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo. And earlier, in 2002, more than 370 died when a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travellers.\n\nIn November 2012 a speeding train crashed into a bus carrying children to their nursery in the country's south, killing more than 50. "ALEXANDRIA, Egypt (AFP) - The death toll from Egypt's latest train disaster rose to 41 as cranes worked on Saturday (Aug 12) to clear the stricken railway line between Cairo and the Mediterranean city of Alexandria.\n\nUnder floodlights, rescue teams had combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties, also using torches on their mobile phones.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when two trains collided near Alexandria rose to 41 dead and 179 wounded, the health ministry said on Saturday.\n\nForty-seven of the wounded have been discharged from hospital while 12 remained in intensive care, it said in a statement.\n\nGet The Straits Times\n\nnewsletters in your inboxSign Up\n\nA stream of ambulances had ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt. The other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority. The crash was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the heavily-used rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in north-western Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into a bus, a lorry and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nAt least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in August 2006 in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, a court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for Footage from the crash site showed medics working to clear the injured from several derailed carriages.\n\nTwo trains collided outside the coastal city of Alexandria on Friday, killing at least 36 people, Egypt's health ministry said in a statement.\n\nThe deadly crash also injured 123 people, the ministry statement said.\n\nThe incident reportedly took place near the Khorshid station and involved one train that was en route from the capital Cairo while the other was coming from the city of Port Said.\n\nImages of the crash site broadcast on state television showed that several carriages had derailed as a result of the collision and that one train had partly keeled over.\n\nThe footage also showed bodies covered with bed sheets lying near the tracks while medics worked to move the dead and injured to ambulances.
