torches on their mobile phones.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when two trains hurtled into each other near Alexandria has risen to 40 dead and 123 wounded, said health ministry spokesperson Khaled Moujahed, as local media said the number of fatalities was likely to rise.\n\nA stream of ambulances ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nDeadly North African accidents\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the busy rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in north-western Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into a bus, a lorry and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nAt least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in August 2006 in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, a court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died when a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 1492, "textStart": 1479}, {"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 2323, "textStart": 2314}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 2598, "textStart": 2587}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T11:42:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"uri": "news24.com", "title": "news24", "id": "309"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:42:00", "url": "http://www.news24.com/World/News/egypt-train-crash-toll-hits-40-as-cranes-clear-busy-link-20170812", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8785689", "image": "http://cdn.24.co.za/files/Cms/General/d/4216/e4bc0b05f22c42b69329eff1883bb97c.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "11:42:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"Disaster struck when two trains - one travelling from Cairo, the other from Port Said - smashed into each other head-on\n\nA TRAIN crash in Egypt has left 28 people dead and 80 others injured, according to officials.\n\nDisaster struck when two trains - one travelling from Cairo, the other from Port Said - collided in Alexandria, local media reports.\n\nIt is not immediately clear what exactly caused the crash, which saw the trains smash into each other head on by the Suez Canal.\n\nBut state TV quoted transport ministry officials as saying there had probably been a malfunction in one of the trains that brought it to a halt on the rails.\n\nThe other train is then believed to have crashed into it.\n\nThe head of the ambulance service in the city's western sector, Dr Mohamed Abu Homs, said the collision took place in the western suburb of Khorshid.\n\nFootage broadcast on state television showed one train had partly keeled over in the crash, and medics were seen moving the dead and injured to ambulances.\n\nState newspaper al-Ahram said 28 bodies had arrived at hospital morgues in Alexandria province.\n\nPublic prosecutor Nabil Sadek ordered an urgent investigation, it said.\n\nAbu Homs said he fears the death toll and the number of injured could rise further.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a November 2013 collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of Cairo.\n\nAnd 373 people lost their lives when a fire ripped through a packed train south of the capital in 2002.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, At least 36 people were killed and more than 123 others were injured Friday in a crash between two trains in Egypt's Alexandria province, Egypt's Health Ministry said.\n\nThe ministry has announced state of emergency in all hospitals in Alexandria and neighboring Beheira province.\n\nSome 75 ambulances have been transferring the victims to hospitals, said the ministry in a statement.\n\nIt added that the number of casualties may rise due to the seriousness of many injuries.\n\nThe Alexandria-bound train coming from Cairo crashed into the rear of another train on its way from Port Said Mediterranean city to Alexandria.\n\nThe accident took place in Kourshid area, east of the coastal city of Alexandria.\n\nEgypt's general prosecutor has ordered an urgent investigation into the accident.\n\nMeanwhile, Egyptian Prime Minister Sherif Ismail gave orders to send giant truck-loaded cranes to help rescue teams remove the destroyed parts of the trains.\n\nEgypt has witnessed a "Central Security Forces"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Security_Forces", "score": 1, "id": "1041523", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "CAIRO- 12 August 2017: In one of the worst train collisions in Alexandria, 42 people were killed and more than 130 injured on Friday. The collision took place in the Khorshid district of the Mediterranean city Alexandria, where two passenger trains, coming from Cairo and Port Said, crashed.\n\nPresident Abel Fatah al-Sisi, immediately following the accident, stated that \"Everyone responsible for the accident will be questioned and punished.\"\n\nSisi affirmed that the all of the state's entities and bodies will work to offer the needed care for the victims and their families, and that all of the culprits will be punished.\n\nTransportation Minister Hisham Arafat on Friday ordered two railway officials and two control tower operators to be suspended from work after the train accident.\n\nThis is considered the third major train crash in Alexandria during the last ten years.\n\nBack in October 1998, around 50 died and more than 80 were injured in a derailment just south of Alexandria.\n\nIn November 1999, a train travelling between Cairo and Alexandria hit a truck and derailed, killing 10 and causing 7 injuries.\n\nEgypt as a whole has a history of train accidents over the past 15 years. Egypttoday provides details of five major train crashes in Egypt:\n\nFebruary 2002: 300 people died while travelling from Cairo to Aswan in the south. This accident was caused by a fire that swept through an overcrowded train. It is considered the worst disaster to hit the country's railway system in the past 25 years.The transportation minister at the time was forced to resign as a result.\n\nAugust 2006: At least 58 people were killed and 143 injured when two passenger trains heading to Cairo from the Nile Delta towns of Mansoura and Benha collided.\n\nOctober 2009: Two trains collided in the el-Ayat area, leaving 30 killed and many others injured. The first train had broken down and was rear-ended by the second. Transport Minister Mohammed Lutfi Mansour resigned three days after the accident.\n\nNovember 2012: A school bus was hit by a train in central Egypt, and 50 children, aged four to six years old, and the driver of the bus were killed. This accident happened near Manfalut, 350km (230 miles) south of Cairo. The transport minister resigned in the wake of the accident.\n\nJanuary 2013: A military train derailed, killing 19 and injuring more than 100. The train, which was heading to Cairo from Assuit and carried new recruits of the Egyptian Central Security Forces, derailed in the Egyptian city of Badrashin.\n\nAccording to the Central Agency for Public Mobilization and Statistics (CAPMAS) in 2016, Egypt has witnessed an average of 1,041 train accidents on an annual basis in the last 12 years.\n\nA total of 13,539 train accidents occurred between 2004 and 2016, reports CAPMAS, citing numbers released by the National Railway Authority of Egypt.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 21, "textStart": 7}, {"amb": false, "date": "1998-10-", "textEnd": 898, "textStart": 886}, {"amb": false, "date": "1999-11-", "textEnd": 1004, "textStart": 991}, {"amb": false, "date": "2002-02-", "textEnd": 1270, "textStart": 1257}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 1594, "textStart": 1583}, {"amb": false, "date": "2009-10-", "textEnd": 1757, "textStart": 1745}, {"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 2005, "textStart": 1992}, {"amb": false, "date": "2013-01-", "textEnd": 2287, "textStart": 2275}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T12:45:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"uri": "egypttoday.com", "title": "Egypt Today", "id": "18008"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:45:00", "url": "http://www.egypttoday.com/Article/1/16898/Egypt-s-train-accidents-when-will-we-stop-counting?fbrefresh=true", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8792663", "image": "http://www.egypttoday.com/images/larg/16751.jpg?fbrefresh=true", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "12:45:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sleeping_while_on_duty", "score": 2, "id": "565131", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The death toll from Egypt's latest train disaster rose to 40 as cranes worked Saturday to clear the stricken railway line between Cairo and the Mediterranean city of Alexandria.\n\nUnder floodlights, rescue teams combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties, also using torches on their mobile phones.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when two trains hurtled into each other near Alexandria has risen to 40 dead and 123 wounded, said health ministry spokesman Khaled Moujahed, as local media said the number of fatalities was likely to rise.\n\nA stream of ambulances ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the busy rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwestern Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into a bus, a lorry and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nAt least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in August 2006 in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, a court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died when a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 1441, "textStart": 1428}, {"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 2272, "textStart": 2263}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 2546, "textStart": 2535}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T09:44:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"uri": "digitaljournal.com", "title": "digitaljournal.com", "id": "556"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:44:00", "url": "http://www.digitaljournal.com/news/world/egypt-train-crash-toll-hits-40-as-cranes-clear-busy-link/article/499821", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8772710", "image": "http://www.digitaljournal.com/img/1/0/4/8/0/9/3/i/3/5/2/p-large/3ee2f13f4ae5faaa58b3c8bdeeac9207f2486ad8.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "09:44:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

{"eng": "Egyptian National Railways"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptian_National_Railways", "score": 3, "id": "634821", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "ALEXANDRIA, Egypt -- Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing 43 people, according to authorities, the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade.\n\nMagdy Hegazy, a top health official in Alexandria, said that along with the 43 killed, the crash also injured 122 people.\n\nThe Egyptian Railways Authority said earlier that a train coming from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of a train that was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAssociated Press footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks.\n\nAmbulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured.\n\nA witness who lives close to the crash site said he and others ran toward the site when they heard the sound of the impact.\n\n\"We ran to the scene and we found people jumping from the train and lots of dead,\" said Abdel-Bari Abdel-Hamid.\n\nBy nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage from the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nFriday's crash was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years. Figures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the number reached 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T02:40:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"uri": "tampabay.com", "title": "Tampa Bay Times", "id": "2249"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:40:00", "url": "http://www.tampabay.com/news/world/train-collision-in-northern-egypt-kills-dozens-wvideo/2333520", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8734417", "image": "http://www.tampabay.com/resources/images/dti/rendered/2017/08/a4s_egypt081217_19797751_8col.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "02:40:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

casualties, also using torches on their mobile phones.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when two trains collided near Alexandria rose to 41 dead and 179 wounded, the health ministry said on Saturday.\n\nForty-seven of the wounded have been discharged from hospital while 12 remained in intensive care, it said in a statement.\n\nA stream of ambulances had ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the heavily-used rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwestern Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into a bus, a lorry and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nAt least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in August 2006 in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, a court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died as a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 1299, "textStart": 1286}, {"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 2138, "textStart": 2129}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 2412, "textStart": 2401}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T12:24:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"uri": "guardian.ng", "title": "guardian.ng", "id": "2274"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:24:00", "url": "https://guardian.ng/news/world/egypt-train-crash-toll-hits-41-as-cranes-clear-busy-link/", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8790111", "image": "https://guardian.ng/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Egypt-train-crash-640x360.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "12:24:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"634821", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "CAIRO (AP) - Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing at least 31 people and injuring about 109, according to two medical officials.\n\nTwo senior medical officials in Alexandria, Mohammed Abu Homs and Magdy Hegazy, gave the casualty tolls. Abu Homs said the death toll was likely to rise further.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Railways Authority said a train traveling to Alexandria from Cairo, Egypt's capital, hit the back end of another train, which was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just west of Alexandria.\n\nThe stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement.\n\nThe statement did not say what caused the accident, saying only that the authority's experts would be investigating.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management. Friday's collision was the latest in a series of deadly accidents that have claimed hundreds of lives over the years.\n\nLocal television stations broadcast images of mangled train coaches on the tracks as crowds gathered around trying to help the victims, with ambulances standing by.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. Sherif Wadie said that the number of casualties could increase.\n\nThe ministry said 75 ambulances had been deployed at the crash scene to treat casualties and that all the hospitals in Alexandria had been placed on high alert.\n\nThe cause of the crash is not yet known.\n\nThe Health ministry is yet to announce the final toll. At least 37 people have been killed and 123 injured in the accident.\n\nTrain accidents are common in Egypt. In 2016, a train derailed in south of Cairo, killing five people, and injuring 27 people in the al-Ayat area.\n\nAnother train derailment in Badr Rashin in Giza killed at least 19 people in 2013.\n\nIn 2012, a collision between a train and school bus on a rail crossing in the town of Manaflut in Upper Egypt killed 51 people, mostly children.\n\nAt least 360 people were killed in 2002 in Egypt's worst train disaster when a major fire engulfed seven carriages of an overcrowded passenger train.\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:46:00Z", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "source": {"uri": "dnaindia.com", "title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "id": "492"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:46:00", "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-egypt-train-collision-kills-37-injures-over-120-2527407", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8690591", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:46:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

brought it to a halt on the rails.\n\nThe head of the ambulance service in the city's western sector, Dr Mohamed Abu Homs, said the collision took place in the western suburb of Khorshid.\n\nFootage families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nALEXANDRIA: The death toll from Egypt's latest train disaster rose to 40 as cranes worked Saturday to clear the stricken railway line between Cairo and the Mediterranean city of Alexandria.\n\nUnder floodlights, rescue teams combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties, also using torches on their mobile phones.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident when two trains hurtled into each other near Alexandria has risen to 40 dead and 123 wounded, said health ministry spokesman Khaled Moujahed, as local media said the number of fatalities was likely to rise.\n\nA stream of ambulances ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe probe, however, did not prevent further accidents. Just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nThere have been many other fatal crashes on the busy rail network.\n\nIn July 2008, at least 44 people died near Marsa Matruh in northwestern Egypt when a runaway truck hurtled into a bus, a lorry and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nAt least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 injured in August 2006 in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, a court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways dates back to 2002 when 373 people died when a fire ripped through a crowded train south of the capital.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 1613, "textStart": 1600}, {"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-", "textEnd": 2444, "textStart": 2435}, {"amb": false, "date": "2006-08-", "textEnd": 2718, "textStart": 2707}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T09:59:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"uri": "freemalaysiatoday.com", "title": "Free Malaysia Today", "id": "10786"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:59:00", "url": "http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/world/2017/08/12/egypt-train-crash-toll-hits-40-as-cranes-clear-busy-link/", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8774380", "image": "http://s3media.freemalaysiatoday.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Alexandria.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "09:59:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"wiki"}], "body": "(Newser) - Two passenger trains collided on Friday just outside Egypt's Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing 43 people, according to authorities, the country's deadliest rail accident in more than a decade. Magdy Hegazy, a top health official in Alexandria, said that along with the 43 killed, the crash also injured 122 people, the AP reports. The Egyptian Railways Authority said earlier that a train coming from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the back of a train that was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria. The stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit, according to the statement. The statement did not say what caused the accident, only that the authority's experts would investigate.\n\nAP footage from the scene showed mangled train coaches on the tracks and several others derailed as hundreds of onlookers and victims' relatives gathered around on both sides of the tracks. Ambulances were standing by and riot police and soldiers were deployed to keep the onlookers away from the scene of the disaster. Residents from nearby homes rushed to the scene to look for survivors inside crushed train carriages or offer first aid to the injured. By nightfall, cranes aided by floodlights began to remove the wreckage off the tracks to allow rail traffic to resume. Rescue teams, meanwhile, continued to look for more bodies and injured passengers inside the carriages. Egypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management. Friday's accident was the deadliest rail accident since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T21:48:00Z", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "source": {"uri": "newser.com", "title": "Newser", "id": "851"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "21:48:00", "url": "http://www.newser.com/story/247100/egypts-deadliest-rail-accident-in-over-a-decade-kills-43.html", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8707132", "image": "http://img1-azcdn.newser.com/image/1136952-12-20170811161908.jpeg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "21:48:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

ministry officials, quoted on state television, said the crash was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt on the rails.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne train had been heading from Cairo to the northern city of Alexandria and the other from the canal city of Port Said, east of the capital, to Alexandria.\n\nThe dead and injured were initially placed on blankets in a field beside the tracks running through farmland on the outskirts of the city.\n\nThe health ministry said 75 ambulances had been dispatched to treat casualties and that all the hospitals in Alexandria had been placed on high alert.\n\nAssistant health minister Sharif Wadi told state television that most of the injured had been transferred to hospital.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster, his office said.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident had jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThe accident was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\n- String of accidents -\n\nThe probe, however, Image: Tang Jiefeng/PA Images\n\nTWO TRAINS HAVE collided outside the Egyptian city of Alexandria, killing at least 36 people, a health ministry official said.\n\nThe crash also injured 123 people, Sharif Wadi, an assistant to the health minister, told state television.\n\nFootage on the state broadcaster showed one train had partly keeled over in the crash, and medics were seen moving the dead and injured to ambulances.\n\nState television, citing transport ministry officials, reported that the crash was probably caused by a malfunction in one of the trains that brought it to a halt on the rails.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nThe dead and injured were initially placed on blankets by the sides of the tracks amid farmland on the outskirts of the Mediterranean city.\n\nWadi told state television that most of the injured have been taken to hospital.\n\nEgypt's transport minister has ordered an investigation into the crash, pledging to \"hold accountable\" whoever was responsible, state television reported.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a November 2013 collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of Cairo.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nThat accident came months after a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people, and almost a year after 47 schoolchildren were killed when a train crashed into their bus.\n\nBoth the transport minister and the head of the railway authority head were forced to resign as a result of that accident, which was blamed on a train signal operator who fell asleep on the job.\n\nThe government also formed a panel to investigate the incident, but that did not prevent further accidents.\n\nEgyptians have long complained that the government has failed to deal with chronic transport problems, with roads as poorly maintained as railway lines.\n\nIn Egypt's "Two trains collided in Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria on Friday killing 42 people and injuring 133 others, the health ministry said. Egyptians search for survivors at the site of a crash where two trains collided near the Khorshid station in Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria, Egypt August 11, 2017.Reuters\n\nTwo trains collided in Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria on Friday killing 42 people and injuring 133 others, the health ministry said.\n\nA witness said the trains rose into the air \"forming a pyramid\" as they slammed into each other just outside a suburban station in the Mediterranean port city.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi ordered an inquiry into the crash, which left bodies strewn on the ground as rescue teams worked to pull the dead and injured from the wrecked carriages.\n\nThe collision at 2:15 pm (1215 GMT), near Khorshid station at the edge of Alexandria, derailed the engine of one train and two cars of the other, the Egyptian Railway Authority said.\n\nA railroad switching error was the most likely cause, a security source said without giving further details.\n\nTransport Minister Hisham Arafat said \"human error\" led to the collision but did not elaborate.\n\n\"In order to avoid it, we have to develop the infrastructure,\" he told state television. A project was under way to improve the area's facilities, but such plans took time and money, he said.\n\nEgyptians look at the crash of two trains that collided near the Khorshid station in Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria, Egypt August 11, 2017.Reuters\n\nOne resident, Hoda, was standing on her rooftop when she saw the trains plow into each other. \"They rose in the air forming a pyramid when they collided,\" she said. \"I started to scream from the rooftops for people to grab some sheets and run.\"\n\n\"The train I was riding was going very quickly,\" said passenger Moumen Youssef. \"I found myself on the floor. When we came out, we found four train cars crushed and a lot of people on the ground.\"\n\nEgyptians have long complained that successive governments failed to enforce basic safeguards for the railways. A string of crashes have further inflamed public anger over the antiquated transport network.\n\nIn 2012, a train rammed into a school bus south of Cairo and killed 50 people, mostly children.\n\nIn Egypt's worst train disaster, a fire tore through seven carriages of an overcrowded passenger train in 2002, killing at least 360 people.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 303, "textStart": 288, "freq": 2}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T13:45:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.co.in", "title": "International Business Times, India Edition", "id": "317"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:45:00", "url": "http://www.ibtimes.co.in/least-42-killed-133-injured-egypt-train-crash-738227", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8803651", "image": "http://data1.ibtimes.co.in/en/full/658319/egypt-train-accident.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "13:45:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

The other train then crashed into it.\n\nOne of the trains had been heading from Cairo to the northern city of Alexandria and the other from the canal city of Port Said, east of the capital, to Alexandria.\n\nThe health ministry said 75 ambulances had been dispatched to treat casualties and that all the hospitals in Alexandria had been placed on high alert.\n\nEgyptian President Abdel Fattah Al-Sisi sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster, his office said, according to AFP.\n\nThe accident is the deadliest train accident in Egypt since a train ploughed into a bus carrying schoolchildren in November 2012, killing 47 people.\n\nThat accident caused the government to order an investigation, but just months later, a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people.\n\nAround a year later, a collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of the capital.\n\n(Arutz Sheva's North American desk is keeping you updated until the start of Shabbat in New York. train had partly keeled over in the crash, and medics were seen moving the dead and injured to ambulances. State television, citing transport ministry officials, reported that the crash was probably caused by a malfunction in one of the trains that brought it to a halt on the rails.\n\nThe dead and injured were initially placed on blankets by the sides of the tracks amid farmland on the outskirts of the Mediterranean city.\n\nWadi told state television that most of the injured have been taken to hospital.\n\nEgypt's transport minister has ordered an investigation into the crash, pledging to \"hold accountable\" whoever was responsible, state television reported. "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCairo -- A train collision near Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria on Friday killed at least 28 people and injured 80 others, Egyptian officials said.\n\nThe two trains collided head on -- one was coming from the capital of Cairo, to the south of Alexandria, and the other was coming from the city of Port Said, located on the northern tip of the Suez Canal.\n\nThe head of the ambulance services in the Alexandria's western sector, Dr. Mohamed Abu Homs, said the collision took place in the district of Khorshid, southeast of the city.\n\nThere was no immediate information on what had caused the collision.\n\nAbu Homs said he fears the death toll and the number of injured could rise further.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record, mostly blamed on decades of badly maintained equipment and poor management.\n\nState TV broadcast images of mangled train coaches on the tracks as crowds gathered around trying to help the reported on Friday.\n\nThe accident occurred near the city's Khorshid train station when a train traveling from Cairo slammed into the back of a train from Port Said, on the Suez Canal, Egypt's railway authority said.\n\nPhotos on social media and published in Egypt news media outlets showed hundreds of people standing outside mangled carriages, several of which had derailed. A number of bodies were laid out on dusty ground beside a field, covered in sheets.\n\nState media said that 28 people had died and at least 109 were injured. "315421", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Al-Ahram"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Ahram", "score": 3, "id": "334811", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Politics of Egypt"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics_of_Egypt", "score": 1, "id": "407964", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Grim images are leaving Egypt today as emergency responders answer the call of a #train collision in #Alexandria. Currently, reports from Egypt's Health Ministry have counted at least 40 fatalities. Rescuers have also counted at least 133 injured in the wreckage. Investigators are thoroughly combing through the scene looking for clues as to what may have caused this deadly incident. Egypt has a history of train crashes, but this is the deadliest one in many years.\n\nReports from the state news agency Al-Ahram said that two trains collided at a station in the district of Khorshid near the seaside city of Alexandria.\n\nOne train was coming in from Cairo, and the other was heading in from Port Said. The fatal accident occurred when the Cairo train rammed into the back of the train from Port Said, which was stationary.\n\nTransport ministry officials are now speculating that the incident was caused by a malfunction in the Port Said train, causing it to come to a halt. The results were catastrophic, leaving at least 40 people dead and 133 injured. Over 75 emergency vehicles showed up to the scene of the incident to transport the wounded to local hospitals.\n\nSurvivors immediately took to social media to share images of the crash. Many described the incident as being shocking.\n\nMoumen Youssef reported to Reuters that the train was traveling at fast speeds when he was suddenly thrust onto the floor.\n\n\"When we came out, we found four train cars crushed and a lot of people on the ground,\" Youssef said.\n\nWitnesses said that civilians rushed to the scene to help the injured passengers. Many brought tools such as welding equipment to help free people who may have been stuck under the wreckage.\n\nWater and sugar were provided by local women, and several men used their trucks to help clear out some of the debris.\n\nThis fatal incident has reignited national anger over the country's poor #Public Transportation System.\n\nThe deadliest public transportation incident to ever occur in Egypt happened in 2002. A fire erupted in an overcrowded train, killing 373 people.\n\nIn 2012, at least 47 children were killed or seriously injured when a train hit their school bus.\n\nIn 2013, a train derailed, leaving 17 people dead. This train was carrying military conscripts.\n\nLater in 2013, a train collided with another bus near Cairo. This incident left 27 people dead. The bus passengers were returning to the city from a wedding when the train slammed into them.\n\nIn response to today's accident, President Sisi has promised financial compensation to the families of the victims. He has also stated that a full investigation will be underway. In the past, the Egyptian government has made investigations, but has failed to make the proper changes that would ensure the safety of passengers.\n\nThis is the first fatal train accident to occur under President Sisi's watch. accident had jolted the government which ordered an investigation and sacked the transport minister and the head of the railway authority.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train bus, truck and several cars waiting at a level crossing, shunting the vehicles into the path of a train.\n\nIn August 2006, at least 58 Egyptians were killed and 144 wounded in a collision between two trains travelling on the same track.\n\nIn the wake of that crash, an Egyptian court sentenced 14 railway employees to one year in prison for neglect.\n\nThe deadliest accident on Egypt's railways If you'd like to learn more...\n\nTwo trains collided in Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria on Friday killing 37 people and injuring 123 others, the health ministry said.\n\nOne eyewitness said the two trains mounted into the air \"forming a pyramid\" after they slammed into each other at a suburban station on the edge of the Mediterranean port city.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi ordered authorities to establish who was responsible for the crash, which left bodies strewn on the ground around wrecked carriages.\n\nStory continues below\n\nREAD MORE: Missed defect in improperly repaired rail caused Gogama, Ont. derailment\n\nThe collision at 2:15 p.m. (1215 GMT), near Khorshid station at the edge of Alexandria, derailed the locomotive of one train and two cars of the other, the Egyptian Railway Authority said.\n\nState newspaper al-Ahram said earlier that 36 bodies had been taken to hospital morgues in Alexandria province.\n\nAs rescue teams pulled dead and injured from the damaged rail wagons, public prosecutor Nabil Sadek ordered an urgent investigation.\n\nA railroad switching error most likely caused the crash, a security source said without giving further details.\n\nOne resident, Hoda, was standing on her rooftop when she saw the trains collide.\n\n\"They rose in the air forming a pyramid when they collided,\" she said. \"I started to scream from the rooftops for people to grab some sheets and run.\"\n\nA health ministry spokesman said 75 ambulances had been deployed at the crash scene. Some people were still stuck inside the trains, a medical official told state TV.\n\nState television showed dozens of people crowding around the damaged train cars, with bodies strewn on the ground.\n\n\"The train I was riding was going very quickly,\" said passenger Moumen Youssef. \"I found myself on the floor. When we came out, we found four train cars crushed and a lot of people on the ground.\"\n\nEgyptians have long complained that successive governments failed to enforce basic safeguards for the railways, leading to a string of fatal crashes.\n\nIn 2012, a train plowed into a school bus south of Cairo and killed 50 people, mostly children, inflaming public anger over Egypt's antiquated transport network.\n\nIn Egypt's worst train disaster, a fire tore through seven carriages of an overcrowded passenger train in 2002, killing at least 360 people.\n\nRELATED: 56 injured, 1 seriously, in Spanish train crash", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:16:00Z", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "source": {"uri": "globalnews.ca", "title": "Global News", "id": "501"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:16:00", "url": "http://globalnews.ca/news/3663956/trains-crash-egypt/", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8686483", "image": "https://shawglobalnews.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/2017-08-11t160220z_96336579_rc18b5fd8900_rtrmadp_3_egypt-crash.jpg?quality=70&strip=all&w=720&h=480&crop=1", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:16:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

(Xinhua/Asmaa Abdelatif)\n\nCAIRO, Aug. 11 -- As Egyptians mourn the victims of a deadly train collision that killed 49, Egypt's President Abdel-Fattah al-Sisi ordered state bodies to hold those responsible accountable.\n\nSisi has ordered an investigation into the cause of the collision, official MENA news agency reported.\n\nEarlier in the day, an Alexandria-bound train coming from Cairo crashed into the rear of another train on its way from Port Said Mediterranean city to Alexandria, killing 49 people and injuring more than 100 others.\n\nThe accident took place in Kourshid area, east of the coastal city of Alexandria.\n\nSisi expressed his deepest sorrow and condolences to the families of the victims, stressing that the government will provide full care for the wounded.\n\nMeanwhile, the health ministry announced that a state of emergency has been declared across Alexandria and neighboring Beheira and Gharbiya provinces.\n\nThe ministry said some 75 ambulances have been transferring the victims, and the number of casualties may rise due to the seriousness of many injuries.\n\nEgypt's general prosecutor has also ordered an urgent investigation into the accident right after its occurrence, while Prime Minister Sherif Ismail has called for the formation of a specialized committee from the Transport Ministry for the investigation.\n\nTransport Minister Hisham Arafatconfirmed that a panel was formed to investigate the deadly accident, adding that the results of the probe will be announced once it is finished.\n\nHe also promised that those who are responsible for the crash will be brought to justice.\n\nThe Egyptian army has also participated in the rescue.\n\nA military statement said army hospitals have been put on alert to receive the injured.\n\nIt added that two giant truck-loaded cranes have been deployed to help lift the damaged train carriages.\n\nMilitary rescue teams, along with 15 ambulances, have been sent to the site of the collision, the statement added.\n\nMoreover, each family of the victims will receive 50,000 Egyptian pounds (around 2,800 U.S. dollars) as compensation, said Social Solidarity Minister Ghad Wali.\n\nAll those wounded in the crash will receive treatment and get compensation according to their level of injury, the minister said.\n\nEgypt has witnessed a number of deadly train accidents in which hundreds died and injured.\n\nIn 2013, at least 19 were killed in a train derailment in Giza governorate, while a collision between a train and a school bus in 2012 in Upper Egypt killed 51, the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nArafat had told reporters at the scene of the accident that it was not yet clear why the train had stopped but suggested old traffic signals were to blame.\n\n\"We have a big problem we had already announced, which is old traffic signals. Public prosecutor Nabil Sadek ordered an urgent investigation, it said.\n\nA medical official told state TV some wounded people were still stuck in the trains.\n\nFootage on state television showed dozens of people crowding around the damaged train cars, with bodies strewn on the ground.\n\n\"The train I was riding was going very quickly,\" said passenger Moumen Youssef. \"I found myself on the floor. When we came out, we found four train cars crushed and a lot of people on the ground.\"\n\nIn 2012, 50 people - mostly children - were killed when a train crashed into a school bus south of Cairo, further inflaming public anger at authorities over Egypt's antiquated transport network. (AFP Photo)\n\nCAIRO, Aug. 12 (Xinhua) -- As Egyptians mourn the victims of a deadly train collision that killed 49, Egypt's President Abdel-Fattah al-Sisi ordered state bodies to hold those responsible accountable.\n\nSisi has ordered an investigation into the cause of the collision, official MENA news agency reported.\n\nEarlier in the day, an Alexandria-bound train coming from Cairo crashed into the rear of another train on its way from Port Said Mediterranean city to Alexandria, killing 49 people and injuring more than 100 others. The accident took place in Kourshid area, east of the coastal city of Alexandria.\n\nSisi expressed his deepest sorrow and condolences to the families of the victims, stressing that the government will provide full care for the wounded.\n\nMeanwhile, the health ministry announced that a state of emergency has been declared across Alexandria and neighboring Beheira and Gharbiya provinces.\n\nThe ministry said some 75 ambulances have been transferring the victims, and the number of casualties may rise due to the seriousness of many injuries.\n\nEgypt's general prosecutor has also ordered an urgent investigation into the accident right after its occurrence, while Prime Minister Sherif Ismail has called for the formation of a specialized committee from the Transport Ministry for the investigation.\n\nTransport Minister Hisham Arafat confirmed that a panel was formed to investigate the deadly accident, adding that the results of the probe will be announced once it is finished.\n\nHe also promised that those who are responsible for the crash will be brought to justice.\n\nEgypt has witnessed a number of deadly train accidents in which hundreds died and injured.\n\nIn 2013, at least 19 were killed in a train derailment in Giza governorate, while a collision between a train and a school bus in 2012 in Upper Egypt killed 51, mostly children.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 45, "textStart": 30}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 283, "textStart": 276}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T14:04:00Z", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "source": {"uri": "news.xinhuanet.com", "title": "Xinhuanet.com", "id": "942"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:04:00", "url": "http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/12/c_136521019.htm", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8800949", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "14:04:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"body": "ALEXANDRIA -- The death toll from Egypt's latest train disaster rose to 41 on Saturday as two drivers were questioned and cranes worked to clear the stricken railway line between Cairo and the Mediterranean city of Alexandria.\n\nThe drivers of the two trains that collided on Friday have been held for questioning and four railway officials suspended pending the results of a probe into its causes, Transportation Minister Hisham Arafat told an Egyptian broadcaster.\n\nUnder floodlights, rescue teams had combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt.\n\nThe other train then crashed into it.\n\nArafat had told reporters at the scene of the accident that it was not yet clear why the train had stopped, but suggested old traffic signals were to blame.\n\n\"We have a big problem we had already announced, which is old traffic signals. We are completely overhauling them. This section here is being developed,\" he said.\n\nAn injured passenger who was on the stationary train said its departure had been delayed and that it kept stopping en route.\n\n\"It stopped every now and then between stations or before stations for five minutes, I don't know why,\" the man told Dream television station from his hospital bed.\n\n\"Everyone was scattered (by the collision), bodies were flung around,\" he said.\n\nThe toll from Friday's accident rose to 41 dead, the health ministry said on Saturday.\n\nThe accident also wounded 132 people, with 79 being discharged after treatment while 53 remained in hospital on Saturday, Health Minister Ahmed Emad El-Din Rady said.\n\nA stream of ambulances had ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals.\n\nWorkers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line.\n\nOne train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah El-Sissi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster. -- AFP", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T03:43:00Z", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "source": {"uri": "saudigazette.com.sa", "title": "Saudi Gazette", "id": "5204"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:43:00", "url": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/article/515006/World/Mena/Egypt", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8868614", "image": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/uploads/images/2017/08/12/462719.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "03:43:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

crashed into it.\n\nThe dead and injured were initially placed on blankets by the sides of the tracks amid farmland on the outskirts of the Mediterranean city.\n\nWadi told state television that most reported.\n\nIt was the deadliest train accident in the North African country since a November 2013 collision between a train and a bus killed 27 people south of Cairo.\n\nThey had been returning from a wedding when the train ploughed into their bus and a truck at a railway crossing.\n\nThat accident came months after a train carrying military conscripts derailed, killing 17 people, and almost a "id": "1055254", "type": "person"}], "body": "CAIRO, Aug. 11 (Xinhua) -- As Egyptians mourn the victims of a deadly train collision that killed 49, Egypt's President Abdel-Fattah al-Sisi ordered state bodies to hold those responsible accountable.\n\nSisi has ordered an investigation into the cause of the collision, official MENA news agency reported.\n\nEarlier in the day, an Alexandria-bound train coming from Cairo crashed into the rear of another train on its way from Port Said Mediterranean city to Alexandria, killing 49 people and injuring more than 100 others.\n\nThe accident took place in Kourshid area, east of the coastal city of Alexandria.\n\nSisi expressed his deepest sorrow and condolences to the families of the victims, stressing that the government will provide full care for the wounded.\n\nMeanwhile, the health ministry announced that a state of emergency has been declared across Alexandria and neighboring Beheira and Gharbiya provinces.\n\nThe ministry said some 75 ambulances have been transferring the victims, and the number of casualties may rise due to the seriousness of many injuries.\n\nEgypt's general prosecutor has also ordered an urgent investigation into the accident right after its occurrence, while Prime Minister Sherif Ismail has called for the formation of a specialized committee from the Transport Ministry for the investigation.\n\nTransport Minister Hisham Arafat confirmed that a panel was formed to investigate the deadly accident, adding that the results of the probe will be announced once it is finished.\n\nHe also promised that those who are responsible for the crash will be brought to justice.\n\nThe Egyptian army has also participated in the rescue.\n\nA military statement said army hospitals have been put on alert to receive the injured.\n\nIt added that two giant truck-loaded cranes have been deployed to help lift the damaged train carriages.\n\nMilitary rescue teams, along with 15 ambulances, have been sent to the site of the collision, the statement added.\n\nMoreover, each family of the victims will receive 50,000 Egyptian pounds (around 2,800 U.S. dollars) as compensation, said Social Solidarity Minister Ghad Wali.\n\nAll those wounded in the crash will receive treatment and get compensation according to their level of injury, the minister said.\n\nEgypt has witnessed a number of deadly train accidents in killing 42 people and injuring 133 others, the health ministry said.\n\nA witness said the trains rose into the air \"forming a pyramid\" as they slammed into each other just outside a suburban station in the Mediterranean port city.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi ordered an inquiry into the crash, which left bodies strewn on the ground as rescue teams worked to pull the dead and injured from the wrecked carriages.\n\nThe collision at 2.15 pm. (1215 GMT), near Khorshid station at the edge of Alexandria, derailed the engine of one train and two cars of the other, the Egyptian Railway Authority said.\n\nA railroad switching error was the most likely cause, a security source said without giving further details.\n\nTransport Minister Hisham Arafat said \"human error\" led to the collision but did not elaborate.\n\n\"In order to avoid it, we have to develop the infrastructure,\" he told state television. A project was under way to improve the area's facilities, but such plans took time and money, he said.\n\nOne resident, Hoda, was standing on her rooftop when she saw the trains plough into each other. \"They rose in the air forming a pyramid when they collided,\" she said. \"I started to scream from the rooftops for people to grab some sheets and run.\"\n\n\"The train I was riding was going very quickly,\" said passenger Moumen Youssef. \"I found myself on the floor. When we came out, we found four train cars crushed and a lot of people on the ground.\"\n\nEgyptians have long complained that successive governments failed to enforce basic safeguards for the railways. A string of crashes have further inflamed public anger over the antiquated transport network.\n\nIn 2012, a train rammed into a school bus south of Cairo and killed 50 people, mostly children.\n\nIn Egypt's worst train disaster, a fire tore through seven carriages of an overcrowded passenger train in 2002, killing at least 360 people. -- REUTERS", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T20:53:00Z", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "source": {"uri": "nst.com.my", "title": "New Straits Times Online", "id": "5690"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:44:00", "url": "https://www.nst.com.my/node/266802", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8744165", "image": "https://assets.nst.com.my/images/articles/train12_field_image_socialmedia.var_1502491795.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "20:53:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"body": "CAIRO -- Two passenger trains collided on the outskirts of the Egyptian city of Alexandria on Friday, killing 36 people and injuring more than 120 others, the government and state media said.\n\nThe injured were transported to hospitals in Alexandria and the neighboring province of Beheira, said Khaled Megahed, a spokesman for the Egyptian Health Ministry.\n\n\"A state of emergency is in place in hospitals in Alexandria and Beheira,\" he added.\n\nThe collision occurred when a passenger train en route from Cairo to Alexandria rammed into the rear of another coming from the Suez Canal city of Port Said, newspaper Al-Ahram reported.\n\nThe cause of the accident was not immediately clear.\n\nState television reports showed pictures of bodies covered with bed sheets at the site. Footage showed that some of the carriages had derailed as a result of the collision.\n\nSenior government officials, including the ministers of transport and health, arrived at the site of the accident and oversaw the evacuation the victims, state media reported.\n\nThe country's chief prosecutor, Nabil Sadeq, ordered an urgent probe into the accident.\n\nThe Mediterranean city of Alexandria is a popular summer resort.\n\nFriday's accident took place less than a month before Eid al-Adha, a major Muslim festival during which Egyptians usually depend on trains to travel to their hometowns for family reunions.\n\nIn recent years, Egypt has seen several rail tragedies.\n\nIn November 2012, 49 people, including 44 children, were killed when a school bus collided with a train in southern Egypt.\n\nThe country's worst rail disaster took place in 2002 when a train heading to southern Egypt caught fire, killing more than 360 people.\n\nVisit Deutsche Presse-Agentur GmbH (Hamburg, Germany) at www.dpa.de/English.82.0.html", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-11-", "textEnd": 1455, "textStart": 1442}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:39:00Z", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette", "id": "984"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:39:00", "url": "http://gazette.com/36-killed-scores-injured-in-egypt-train-collision/article/feed/483653", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8689754", "image": "//s3.amazonaws.com/assets.gazette/img/g-mtn.png", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:39:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Friday killing 42 people and injuring 133 others, the health ministry said.\n\nA witness said the trains rose into the air \"forming a pyramid\" as they slammed into each other just outside a suburban station in the Mediterranean port city.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi ordered an inquiry into the crash, which left bodies strewn on the ground as rescue teams worked to pull the dead and injured from the wrecked carriages.\n\nThe collision at 2:15 p.m. (1215 GMT), near Khorshid station at the edge of Alexandria, derailed the engine of one train and two cars of the other, the Egyptian Railway Authority said.\n\nA railroad switching error was the most likely cause, a security source said without giving further details.\n\nTransport Minister Hisham Arafat said \"human error\" led to the collision but did not elaborate.\n\n\"In order to avoid it, we have to develop the infrastructure,\" he told state television. A project was under way to improve the area's facilities, but such plans took time and money, he said.\n\nOne resident, Hoda, was standing on her rooftop when she saw the trains plow into each other. \"They rose in the air forming a pyramid when they collided,\" she said. \"I started to scream from the rooftops for people to grab some sheets and run.\"\n\n\"The train I was riding was going very quickly,\" said passenger Moumen Youssef. \"I found myself on the floor. When we came out, we found four train cars crushed and a lot of people on the ground.\"\n\nEgyptians have long complained that successive governments failed to enforce basic safeguards for the railways. A string of crashes have further inflamed public anger over the antiquated transport network.\n\nIn 2012, a train rammed into a school bus south of Cairo and killed 50 people, mostly children.\n\nIn Egypt's worst train disaster, a fire tore through seven carriages of an overcrowded passenger train in 2002, killing at least 360 people.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {"liCnt": 6, "gpCnt": 5}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T20:44:00Z", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "source": {"uri": "reuters.com", "title": "Reuters", "id": "8"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:44:00", "url": "https://www.reuters.com/article/us-egypt-crash-idUSKBN1AR1K1", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8698101", "image": "https://s4.reutersmedia.net/resources/r/?m=02&d=20170811&t=2&i=1196735447&w=&fh=545px&fw=&ll=&pl=&sq=&r=LYNXMPED7A148", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "20:44:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Friday killing 42 people and injuring 133 others, the health ministry said.\n\nA witness said the trains rose into the air \"forming a pyramid\" as they slammed into each other just outside a suburban station in the Mediterranean port city.\n\nPresident Abdel Fattah al-Sisi ordered an inquiry into the crash, which left bodies strewn on the ground as rescue teams worked to pull the dead and injured from the wrecked carriages.\n\nThe collision at 2:15 p.m. (1215 GMT), near Khorshid station at the edge of Alexandria, derailed the engine of one train and two cars of the other, the Egyptian Railway Authority said.\n\nA railroad switching error was the most likely cause, a security source said without giving further details.\n\nTransport Minister Hisham Arafat said \"human error\" led to the collision but did not elaborate.\n\n\"In order to avoid it, we have to develop the infrastructure,\" he told state television. A project was under way to improve the area's facilities, but such plans took time and money, he said.\n\nOne resident, Hoda, was standing on her rooftop when she saw the trains plow into each other. \"They rose in the air forming a pyramid when they collided,\" she said. \"I started to scream from the rooftops for people to grab some sheets and run.\"\n\n\"The train I was riding was going very quickly,\" said passenger Moumen Youssef. \"I found myself on the floor. When we came out, we found four train cars crushed and a lot of people on the ground.\"\n\nEgyptians have long complained that successive governments failed to enforce basic safeguards for the railways. A string of crashes have further inflamed public anger over the antiquated transport network.\n\nIn 2012, a train rammed into a school bus south of Cairo and killed 50 people, mostly children.\n\nIn Egypt's worst train disaster, a fire tore through seven carriages of an overcrowded passenger train in 2002, killing at least 360 people.\n\n(Reporting by Ahmed Mohamed Hassan, Mahmoud Mourad and Ellen Francis; Additional reporting by Mostafa Hashem, Haitham El Sheikh and Osama Naguib; Writing by Ellen Francis; Editing by Louise Ireland)", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:36:00Z", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "title": "yahoo.com", "id": "228"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:55:00", "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/train-crash-egypts-alexandria-kills-21-injures-55-140654445.html", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8754570", "image": "https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/g9eqgsarz8zbBGarvsjXZg--/aD0xMjI0O3c9MTYzMjtzbT0xO2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2017-08-11T155414Z_1289103680_RC1B58012E00_RTRMADP_3_EGYPT-CRASH.JPG", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:36:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marzouq_Al-Ghanim", "score": 3, "id": "652967", "type": "person"}], "body": "ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug 12, (Agencies): The death toll from Egypt's latest train disaster rose to 41 on Saturday as two drivers were questioned and cranes worked to clear the stricken railway line between Cairo and the Mediterranean city of Alexandria. The drivers of the two trains that collided on Friday have been held for questioning and four railway officials suspended pending the results of a probe into its causes, Transportation Minister Hisham Arafat told an Egyptian broadcaster. Under floodlights, rescue teams had combed wrecked carriages all night for casualties. In Kuwait, His Highness the Amir Sheikh Sabah Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah on Friday cabled Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi expressing condolences on death and injury of scores of people in the two trains' accident in Alexandria. His Highness the Amir, in the cable, prayed for souls of the deceased and wished the injured speedy recovery. Their Highnesses the Crown Prince and Prime Minister, respectively Sheikh Nawaf Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah and Sheikh Jaber Al-Mubarak Al-Hamad Al-Sabah, addressed cables of identical content to the Egyptian president.\n\nKuwait's National Assembly Speaker Marzouq Al-Ghanim on Friday sent a cable of condolences to his Egyptian counterpart Ali Abdel-Aal over the victims of the two-train collision in Alexandria. In the cable, Al-Ghanim prayed to Allah the Almighty to bless the souls of victims of the crash and to bring solace to their families, and wished a speedy recovery to the wounded.\n\nTransport ministry officials, quoted on state television, have said the crash in farmland on the outskirts of Alexandria was probably caused by a malfunction in one train that brought it to a halt. The other train then crashed into it. Arafat had told reporters at the scene of the accident that it was not yet clear why the train had stopped, but suggested old traffic signals were to blame. \"We have a big problem we had already announced, which is old traffic signals. We are completely overhauling them. This section here is being developed,\" he said.\n\nAn injured passenger who was on the stationary train said its departure had been delayed and that it kept stopping en route. \"It stopped every now and then between stations or before stations for five minutes, I don't know why,\" the man told Dream television station from his hospital bed. \"Everyone was scattered (by the collision), bodies were flung around,\" he said. The toll from Friday's accident when the two trains collided near Alexandria rose to 41 dead, the health ministry said on Saturday.\n\nThe accident also wounded 132 people, with 79 being discharged after treatment while 53 remained in hospital on Saturday, Health Minister Ahmed Emad el-Din Rady said. A stream of ambulances had ferried the injured, stretched out on the ground in a field alongside the railway tracks, to Alexandria hospitals. Workers used cranes to lift four knotted sheet-metal carriages blocking the normally busy Cairo-Alexandria line. One train had been heading to Alexandria from Cairo and the other from Port Said, east along the coast. President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi has sent his condolences to the victims' families and ordered a probe to \"hold accountable\" those responsible for the disaster.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 25, "textStart": 19}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3354959", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T04:16:00Z", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "source": {"uri": "arabtimesonline.com", "title": "ARAB TIMES", "id": "6862"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:16:00", "url": "http://www.arabtimesonline.com/news/train-crash-toll-egypt-hits-41-amir-voices-sorrow/", "storyUri": "eng-3354959", "id": "8870958", "image": "http://www.arabtimesonline.com/news/file/2017/08/train.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "04:16:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"CAIRO, Aug. 12 (Xinhua) -- Egypt has launched an on-the-spot technical railway check after a recent deadly train crash in Alexandria, which killed 49 people, the general prosecution office said in a statement on Saturday.\n\nEgypt's top prosecutor assigned a military engineering body to perform an on-the-spot technical railway check after the deadly train crash in the coastal city of Alexandria.\n\nThe top prosecutor ordered formation of a seven-member committee from the Armed Forces Engineering Authority and the consultation office of the Military Technical College to issue a report on Friday's two-train collision in seaside northern city of Alexandria that left at least 49 dead and over 130 wounded.\n\nThe committee will also include two members from the country's anti-corruption Administrative Control Authority.\n\n\"The committee's mission is to examine the crash scene and technically check the soundness of the railroad and the traffic light signals and semaphores based on the standards regulated for railway operation,\" said the statement.\n\nMeanwhile, the Transportation Ministry said that the two drivers of the twin trains have been held for questioning and four railway officials have been suspended over the tragedy.\n\nOver the past 15 years, Egypt has witnessed several deadly railway crashes that signaled poor railway conditions and lack of necessary railroad maintenance.\n\nThe worst train accident in Egypt took place at Giza's district of Ayyat in 2002, which killed 350 passengers when fire broke out in a train coming from Upper Egypt, forcing passengers to hopelessly jump out to survive.\n\nAnother train tragedy hit the country 10 years later, particularly in November 2012, when a train hit a school bus at a crossing barrier area in Upper Egypt's Assiut province, killing over 50 children.\n\nLater in early 2013, the derailment of a train in Giza carrying new police recruits left 19 people killed and over 100 killed 49 people, the general prosecution office said in a statement on Saturday.\n\nEgypt's top prosecutor assigned a military engineering body to perform an on-the-spot technical railway check after the deadly train crash in the coastal city of Alexandria.\n\nThe top prosecutor ordered formation of a seven-member committee from the Armed Forces Engineering Authority and the consultation office of the Military Technical College to issue a report on Friday's two-train collision in seaside northern city of Alexandria that left at least 49 dead and over 130 wounded.\n\nThe committee will also include two members from the country's anti-corruption Administrative Control Authority.\n\n\"The committee's mission is to examine the crash scene and technically check the soundness of the railroad and the traffic light signals and semaphores based on the standards regulated for railway operation,\" said the statement.\n\nMeanwhile, the Transportation Ministry said that the two drivers of the twin trains have been held for questioning and four railway officials have been suspended over the tragedy.\n\nOver the past 15 years, Egypt has witnessed several deadly railway crashes that signaled poor railway conditions and lack of necessary railroad maintenance.\n\nThe worst train accident in Egypt took place at Giza's district of Ayyat in 2002, which killed 350 passengers when fire broke out in a train coming from Upper Egypt, forcing passengers to hopelessly jump out to survive.\n\nAnother train tragedy hit the country 10 years later, particularly in November 2012, when a train hit a school bus at a crossing barrier area in Upper Egypt's Assiut province, killing over 50 children.\n\nLater in early 2013, the derailment of a train in Giza carrying new police recruits left 19 people the total number of railway accidents from 2006 until 2016 was 12,236.\n\nThe highest accident rates were in 2009 and reached 1,577 accidents, while the lowest were in 2012 with 447 accidents, due to the traffic suspensions during the January 25 revolution.\n\nAccording to statistical data prepared by the Railways Authority in cooperation with the Central Agency for Mobilization and Statistics (CAPMAS), the highest death rate and injuries occurred in the train accident of Manfalut in December 2012, where 51 were killed, followed by the train accident of Ayyat in 2013 where 15 people were killed and 25 others were injured.\n\nThe statistics showed that in 2016 total accidents amounted to 1,249 compared to 1,235 in 2015 and 1,044 in 2014.\n\nAccidents from cars that crossed railroads and were hit by a train counted for 80 percent of the accidents, while accidents where trains deviated from the track made up 15 percent.\n\nThe most recent train collision on Friday occurred in the Khurshid area near Sidi Gaber station in Alexandria, leaving 42 dead and 133 injured.\n\nUpon inspection of the scene, security sources revealed that the collision happened between a train coming from Cairo and another coming from Port Said. The accident took place at 1:30 pm, Friday.\n\nDirector of Alexandria Security Major General Mostafa al-Nimr received notification from the Sidi Gaber police station about the collision on the outskirts of the Alexandria Governorate, and immediately dispatched security to the scene.\n\nSecurity sources, upon inspection of the scene, revealed that the collision was between a train coming from Cairo and another coming from Port Said. They crashed a few kilometers from Sidi Gaber station, when the Port Said train stopped after a sudden failure, leading the Cairo train to crash into it from behind. Coaches were destroyed and derailed in the collision.\n\nKhalid Ibrahim, an eyewitness, said the residents of Ezbet al-Sheikh al-Soghra village rushed to help the victims of the accident to get them out of the wreckage of the train.\n\nThe Directorate of Health rushed 30 ambulances to the scene of the accident, which took around half an hour to arrive at the scene.\n\nUndersecretary of the Ministry of Health Magdy Hegazi declared a state of emergency in all Alexandria hospitals, and expects the number of casualties to rise.\n\nGovernor of Alexandria Mohamed Sultan arrived at the scene, stressing the accountability of all officials present. Asharq Al-Awsat Arabic\n\nCairo- Public prosecutor Nabil Sadek formed a committee on Saturday that encompasses specialists from the army and the administrative authority to determine the responsible party for the terrible collision of Alexandria trains, which caused casualties.\n\nSecurity and technical sources said that a human fault is likely to have made trains change tracks.\n\nTwo trains collided in Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria on Friday, killing 41 people and injuring more than 132 others, a Health Ministry spokesman said.\n\nFollowing the accident, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi promised to hold accountable those responsible for the disaster and that the state will deploy all its potentials to provide full care for the injured.\n\nA statement by the Egyptian Public Prosecution - issued on Saturday - mentioned that a committee was formed following the order of Nabil Sadek to prepare a full report on the disaster. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi", "label": {"eng": "Abdel Fattah el-Sisi"}, "type": "person", "id": "324948", "score": 2}], "time": "17:52:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "The crash took place on Friday when a train coming from Cairo, Egypt's capital, crashed into the rear of another that was waiting at a small station in the district of Khorshid, just east of Alexandria. The stationary train had just arrived from Port Said, a Mediterranean city on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, when it was hit.\n\nProsecutors ordered the drivers of the Cairo train, his assistant, the driver of the Port Said train and an observation tower lookout to be detained for 15 days pending investigation and accused them of manslaughter and negligence.\n\nThey also requested blood and urine samples from the Cairo driver to test for drugs.\n\nThe officials requested anonymity as they were not authorized to brief reporters.\n\nThe state-run news agency MENA reported that the public prosecutor ordered the chairman of Egypt's Railway Authority and nine other officials to be summoned for interrogation over the accident.\n\nIn a meeting with President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi on Saturday, Transport Minister Hesham Arafat blamed the accident on human error, against a background of heavy reliance on manual operations, and the railway system's poorly maintained infrastructure.\n\nEgypt's railway system has a poor safety record and accidents due to negligence have killed scores over the years.\n\nFigures recently released by the state's statistics agency show that 1,249 train accidents took place last year, the highest number since 2009 when the figure was 1,577.\n\nFriday's accident was the deadliest since 2006, when at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo. In 2002, a massive fire engulfed a train filled with local holiday travelers. That train sped for miles, with flames engulfing one carriage after another, killing more than 370 people.", "timeCrawl": "17:52:00", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "extractedDates": null, "location": null, "originalArticle": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "id": "8949462", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Education_and_Training", "label": "dmoz/Business/Education and Training", "id": 19, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Education/Commercial_Services", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Education/Commercial Services", "id": 184, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Services", "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Services", "id": 319, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Trains_and_Railroads/Organizations", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Trains and Railroads/Organizations", "id": 1107, "wgt": 100}], "details": {}}], "page": 1, "pages": 483, "totalResults": 483}}}
